questions.text:
Which of the following pedigree charts correspond to the pattern of inheritance that would be seen in the case of G6PD deficiency?

G6PD- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
G-6-PD deficiency has an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance as shown in image 1.

Clues for diagnosis of the pattern of inheritance as X-linked recessive:

  • Males are affected and females are carriers.
  • No male-to-male transmission. Females transmit the disease.
  • Affected males have carrier daughters and unaffected sons.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway. Its deficiency commonly manifests as neonatal jaundice and episodic acute hemolytic anaemia. The common provoking agents are infections, some drugs like sulfa drugs/ quinine group, and fava beans.

MELAS (mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes) follows a mitochondrial inheritance pattern as shown below.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

questions.text: A female patient presented to the OPD with a continuous, clear, watery discharge from her nose. She was in a minor RTA 2 days back. She is hemodynamically stable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CSF rhinorrhoea: Leakage of CSF into the nose is called CSF rhinorrhoea

Following features helps in differentiating CSF rhinorrhoea from nasal secretions

Features CSF Fluid Nasal Secretions

History

Nasal or sinus surgery, head injury, or intracranial tumor

Sneezing, nasal stuffiness, itching in the nose, or lacrimation

Flow of discharge

A few drops or a stream of fluid gushes down with bending forward or straining

cannot be sniffed back

Continuous and no effect with bending forward or straining.

Can be sniffed back

Character of discharge

Thin, watery, and clear

Slimy (mucus) or clear (tears)

Taste

Sweet

Salty

Sugar content

More than 30 mg/dL

Less than 10 mg/dl

Presence of β2 transferrin

Always present

 Always absent

Note:

Nasal discharge stiffens the handkerchief because of the presence of mucus.

A basilar skull fracture occurs due to direct impact behind the ear or crush injuries of the head and present with the following features:

  • Hemotympanum
  • Battle sign: bruising behind the ear
  • Racoon eyes
  • CSF rhinorrhoea

Treatment CSF rhinorrhea:

  • Early cases of post traumatic CSF rhinorrhea are managed conservatively by placing the patient in the semi sitting position, avoiding blowing of nose, sneezing and straining.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics are also determined to prevent meningitis.
  • Persistent cases of CSF rhinorrhoea are treated surgically by nasal endoscopic or intracranial approach. Nasal endoscopic approach is useful for leaks from the frontal sinus, cribriform plate, ethmoid or sphenoid sinuses.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: Which is the study design of choice to identify the prevalence of a disease?
questions.solution:
Cross-sectional study is done to identify the prevalence of a disease.

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

 

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Other options:
Option B: An ambispective cohort is the combination of both retrospective and prospective cohort studies.
Option C: In a case-control study, the study begins from the outcome and goes retrospectively to find out the exposure among the cases and controls.
Option D: In case of a prospective cohort study, the study population is followed up regularly to look for the effects of exposure. 

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

Incidence in Epidemiology:

  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.
  • Incidence = (Number of cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time) x 1000
  • Incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year.
  • It provides insight into the effectives of health services and programs.
  • Incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000
  • It is generally used for acute illnesses.
  • Special types of incidence rates:
    • Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.
    • Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.
  • Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Prevalence in Epidemiology:

  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.
  • It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio.
  • It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.
  • Types:
    • Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.
    • Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.
  • Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.
  • Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time) x 100
  • It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

  • Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.
  • Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration
  • Longer the duration of the disease, greater the prevalence.
  • In acute diseases,because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence.This is because in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as duration of disease decreases.
  • If treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A patient presents with a firm, tender, slow-growing mass below the ear as shown in the image below. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of a parotid abscess. 

A parotid abscess refers to an infection and pus formation in the parotid space. It is caused most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus. Post-surgical cases and debilitated patients with stasis of salivary flow are at risk of developing parotid abscesses.

Patients typically present with unilateral swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present. Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan. Multiple small loculi of pus are seen in the parenchyma. Aspiration of abscess can be done to determine the culture and sensitivity of the infective agent. 

Correction of dehydration, improving oral hygiene, and promoting salivary flow. Intravenous antibiotics are also used in treatment. Surgical drainage of the abscess is done via a preauricular incision.

The parotid gland is enclosed by deep cervical fascia which splits into superficial and deep layers. Parotid space lies deep in the superficial layer. Contents of parotid space include : 

  • parotid gland 
  • lymph nodes associated with parotid gland
  • facial nerve 
  • external carotid artery
  • retromandibular vein

Other options: 

Option A: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis and is formed when pus breaks inferiorly, through the tip of the mastoid and collects in the upper part of the neck. The onset is sudden with pain, fever, tender neck swelling, and torticollis. There will be a history of purulent otorrhea.

Option C: Osteoma of the mandible is usually slow growing and asymptomatic. It usually occurs in the mandibular condyle area. They are usually detected incidentally during a radiographic examination.

Option D: Upper cervical lymphadenopathy occurs in the neck region following infection in the area drained by these structures.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a painless swelling near the angle of his jaw,nasal obstruction,decreased hearing ability and occasional epistaxis. On performing hearing tests, conductive hearing loss is seen on the same side as the swelling. Examination of the swelling revealed a single enlarged lymph node, 5 cm in size and systemic examination revealed squint. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests nasopharyngeal carcinoma with cranial nerve involvement (indicating stage IV). The treatment of choice in this condition is radiotherapy + chemotherapy.

The given scenario describes nasal (obstruction and epistaxis), otologic (conductive hearing loss) and ophthalmic symptoms (squint) with cervical lymphadenopathy. This set of symptoms in an elderly man is highly suggestive of a tumor in the nasopharynx, nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma usually originates from the nasopharynx in the fossa of Rossenmuller. It presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal- Nasal obstruction due to blockage of the choana or the nasal cavity, denasal speech, nasal discharge, epistaxis.
  • Otologic- Obstruction of the eustachian tube leads to unilateral conductive hearing loss, serous or suppurative otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmologic- These symptoms occur due to the involvement of cranial nerves.
    • Squint and diplopia- involvement of cranial nerve VI.
    • Facial pain and reduced corneal reflex- cranial nerve V.
    • Exophthalmos and blindness- cranial nerve II.
  • Cervical node metastasis- Usually between the angle of jaw and the mastoid.
  • Distant metastasis- to bone, liver, lung, etc.

The treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Radiotherapy for stages I and II.
  • Radiotherapy + chemotherapy for stages III and IV.
  • Radical neck dissection can be done in case of recurrent or residual disease.

TNM staging of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is given below:

  • T1 Tumour confined to the nasopharynx 
  • T2 Tumour extends to soft tissues of oropharynx and/or nasal fossa
    • T2a without parapharyngeal extension
    • T2b with parapharyngeal extension
  • T3 Tumour invades bony structures and/or paranasal sinuses 
  • T4 Tumour with intracranial extension and/or involvement of cranial nerves, infratemporal fossa, hypopharynx or orbit or masticator space 

     Regional lymph nodes:

  • NX Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
  • N0 No regional lymph node metastasis 
  • N1 Unilateral metastasis in lymph node(s), 6 cm or less in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa
  • N2 Bilateral metastasis in lymph nodes, 6 cm or less in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa.
  • N3 Metastasis in a lymph node(s)
    • N3a Greater than 6 cm in dimension
    • N3b In the supraclavicular fossa

     Metastasis:

  • MX Distant metastasis cannot be assessed
  • M0 No distant metastasis
  • M1 Distant metastasis

     Stage grouping:

questions.text: Postural hypotension is a side effect of which of the following classes of drugs?
questions.solution:
Drug-induced orthostatic/postural hypotension is caused by the effect of alpha-blocker (alpha1 - selective receptor blocker).

Alpha1 receptor blockers, such as prazosin, cause a reduction of peripheral resistance as well as venous pooling of blood. This causes a decrease in venous return and cardiac output leading to a fall in blood pressure. Postural reflex causes marked postural hypotension which leads to syncope. This dizziness and fainting are known as the first dose effect and can be minimized by starting with a minimal dose and titrating it thereafter. Other side effects include reflex tachycardia, miosis, nasal congestion, and impotence. 

They are used as an antihypertensive agent and in benign hypertrophy of the prostate to decrease prostatic tone.

The prostate stroma has a maximum concentration of α1A receptors over other α1 receptor subtypes. α1B receptors are present on blood vessels which play a role in vasoconstriction. Hence, selective α1A receptor antagonists have minimal effect on blood pressure as compared to non-selective α1 antagonists like prazosin.

α1 receptor antagonists can be classified as:

  • Selective antagonists
    • Silodosin (α1A)
    • Tamsulosin (α1A + α1D)
  • Non-selective 
    • Prazosin
    • Terazosin
    • Doxazosin
    • Alfuzosin

Other options:

Option A: Side effects of Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE) Inhibitors include - dry cough, hyperkalemia, angioedema, renal Impairment

Option B: Side effects of Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers (ARB) - hyperkalemia, dizziness

Option C: Side effects of thiazide diuretics include- hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hyperuricemia, hyperglycemia

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination of the nose, she has roomy nasal cavities, foul-smelling discharge, and dry greenish crusts. She is also found to have merciful anosmia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of merciful anosmia, foul-smelling discharge, and roomy nasal cavities, with dry greenish crusts, points to a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The exact etiology of this condition is not known. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. 

Clinically patients present with nasal obstruction, foul odor, and merciful anosmia. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

On examination of the nose, greenish or greyish crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, atrophied nasal turbinates, and epistaxis following the removal of the crusts. The roomy nasal cavity is seen due to the resorption of bones of the turbinates.

Treatment:

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, and sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, oestradiol, and vitamin D2. 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, and placental extract.
  • Surgical management:
    • Young's operation.
    • Modified young operation.
    • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

Other options:

Option B: Nasal polyps are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps. They present with a polypoid mass in the nose.

Option C: Allergic rhinitis is associated with inferior turbinate hypertrophy and can cause chronic nasal obstruction. It is characterized by watery nasal discharge, sneezing, and itching in the nose.

Option D: Foreign body nose is commonly seen in children. The child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

  • More common in females 
  • Usually starts at puberty
  • It is a bilateral condition
  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia)
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing data on some volunteers in a gym. Which of the following statements is true in these volunteers regarding their respiratory adjustment?

choices.text: Activity of joint proprioceptors is important factor in increasing ventilation
Arterio-venous difference in oxygen concentration remains constant

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding respiratory adjustment is that signals from joint proprioceptors play a role in stimulating the respiratory drive during exercise.

Regulation of respiration in exercise

  • During strenuous exercise, O2 consumption and CO2 for­mation can increase as much as 20-fold. Yet in the healthy athlete, the arterial PO2, PCO2, and pH remain almost exactly normal. This is because alveolar ventilation increases along with the increased level of oxygen metabolism.
  • Part of this stimulation of alveolar ventilation results from direct stimulation of the respiratory centre by nervous signals. An additional part is believed to result from sensory signals transmitted into the respiratory centre from the contracting muscles and joint proprioceptors.
  • During strenuous exercise, the utilization of O2 in the entire body can increase by 75%-85%. So, more oxygen is extracted from the arterioles leaving less O2 in the venules. This leads to an increased arterio-venous difference in oxygen concentration.

Related Pearl: Respiratory responses to exercise

Parameter

Response

O2 consumption

↑

CO2 production

↑

Ventilation rate

↑ (matches O2 consumption/CO2 production)

Arterial Po2 and Pco2

No change

Arterial pH

No change in moderate exercise

↓ in strenuous exercise (lactic acidosis)

Venous Pco2

↑

Pulmonary blood flow (cardiac output)

↑

V/Q ratios

More evenly distributed in lung

questions.text: A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presents with swelling on the left side of his neck. Examination reveals a gurgling sound on compression of the swelling. X-ray of the neck is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image along with the examination finding of Bryce sign (on compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling sound) is suggestive of laryngocoele.

Laryngocoele:

  • Air filled cavity within the larynx developing in the saccule.
  • Patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible.
  • Bryce sign.

Other options:

Option A: Zenker diverticulum or pharyngeal pouch is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum and results from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (or dehiscence of Killian). Killian's triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibres of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibres of the thyropharyngeus.

Option C: A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal fistula communication between the Esophagus and Trachea. Type C lesion is associated with proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF, the proximal blind pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF.

Option D: Tonsillar cyst is due to blockage of a tonsillar crypt and appears as a yellowish swelling over the tonsil. Very often it is symptomless. It can be easily drained.

questions.text:
A patient with severe persistent asthma continues to have symptoms despite being on high-dose ICS-LABA therapy. Which of the following is a leukotriene receptor antagonist, appropriate as an add-on therapy for this patient?

ICS-LABA : Inhaled corticosteroids - Long acting bronchodilators
questions.solution:
Zafirlukast can be used as an add-on therapy in this patient.

Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. They are competitive antagonists of the cysLT1 receptors. These drugs act by: 

  • Decreasing bronchoconstriction
  • Reducing airway mucus secretion
  • Decreasing vascular permeability and
  • Reducing eosinophil chemotaxis 

Leukotriene modifiers are less effective than inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) in controlling asthma. They are used as add-on therapy in some patients whose asthma is not controlled with low doses of ICS.

Option A: Dupilumab is an interleukin-4 receptor antagonist used in severe asthma. 

Option B: Roflumilast is a PDE-4 selective inhibitor used in the treatment of COPD.

Option D: Zileuton is a lipoxygenase inhibitor that can be used in the treatment of asthma.

questions.text: Identify the pathological red blood cell form shown in the image below
questions.solution:
The pathological red blood cell form seen in the peripheral smear is an acanthocyte.

Acanthocytes are red blood cells with spicules of various sizes at regular intervals on the cell surface.

Conditions with acanthocytes include-

  • Renal disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy/ hyposplenism.

Other options- 

Option A: Dacrocytes or tear-drop cells are seen in myelofibrosis, myelodysplastic syndromes, hemolytic anemias, and thalassemias.  

 

 Option C: Echinocyte or Burr cells are characterized by projections of the red cell membrane that are smaller, regularly spaced, smoothly rounded crenulations, and much more uniform in shape and distribution in contrast to the acanthocytes. They are seen in anemia of renal disease (uremia), in premature infants, after exchange transfusion, and may sometimes be seen as storage artifacts.

 

Option D: Schistocytes or helmet cells are fragmented RBCs that are seen in microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias and mechanical valves.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes rapid-onset food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

The common sources of infection are foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

questions.text: Surface marking of the oblique fissure of the lung includes  ________
questions.solution:
On either side, the upper and lower lobes of the lung are separated by the oblique fissure.

This can be marked by a line that runs anteroinferiorly from the posterior end of the 4th rib (spinous process of the T3 vertebra), crosses the 5th rib in the mid­axillary line, continues inferiorly, crossing either the 6th intercostal space/ 7th rib on the right or the 5th rib/ 5th intercostal space on the left, on both sides at the mid­clavicular line.

Left oblique fissure is located at a higher level and courses more vertically than the right oblique fissure.

questions.text: The following is a graphical depiction of post-myocardial infarction blood levels of various serum cardiac biomarkers.  Which biomarker does the yellow curve depict?
questions.solution:
The yellow curve here shows the levels of CK-MB (creatine kinase-myoglobin binding) which starts rising around 4-8 hrs post-MI, peaks at 24 hrs, and returns to baseline at 48 to 72 hrs.

questions.text: Perifascicular atrophy is seen in ______________.
questions.solution:
Myofiber atrophy is accentuated at the edges of the fascicles (perifascicular atrophy) seen in dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis

  • Dermatomyositis is an immunologic disease in which damage to small blood vessels contributes to muscle injury.
  • Muscle biopsies of affected patients show infiltrates of mononuclear inflammatory cells that tend to be most pronounced in the perimysial connective tissue and around blood vessels.
  • Sometimes there is a distinctive pattern in which myofiber atrophy is accentuated at the edges of the fascicles— perifascicular atrophy.
  • Segmental fiber necrosis and regeneration may also be seen.

Muscle biopsy findings in dermatomyositis-

questions.text: A person with myasthenia gravis notes increased muscle strength when he is treated with an acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitor.  The basis for his improvement is due to the increase in _______

choices.text: The amount of acetylcholine (ACh) released from motor nerves
The level of ACh at the muscle end plates
The number of ACh receptors on the motor end plates
Synthesis of norepinephrine in motor nerves

questions.solution:
Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g.,neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate.

Myasthenia gravis:

  • It is caused by the presence of antibodies to the ACh receptor.
  • Is characterized by skeletal muscle weakness and fatigability resulting from a reduced number of ACh receptors on the muscle end plate.
  • The size of the EPP (end plate potential) is reduced.
  • Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate, partially compensating for the reduced number of receptors.

questions.text: A man has been arrested and booked under Sec. 304-B IPC. Which of the following offenses has he been accused of?
questions.solution:
Section 304-B of the Indian Penal Code (I.P.C)/ Section 80 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) deals with dowry deaths.

This legal provision comes into effect when the untimely demise of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any other cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Evidence of cruelty or harassment by her spouse or relatives of her spouse in connection with demands for dowry must be shown. An individual accused of dowry death (cognizable, non-bailable) is liable to imprisonment from 7 years to life. 

Other options - 

Option A - Death by rash or negligent act is punishable (imprisonment for up to 2 years with/without fine) by Sec. 304-A IPC. 

Option C - Culpable homicide is punishable by Sec. 299 IPC. It is an offense wherein the accused intentionally causes death or bodily injury likely to cause death.  Culpable homicide is defined under section 100 of the BNS.

Option D -  Grievous hurt is punishable by Sec. 320 IPC (Sec.116 BNS). Grievous hurt refers to any hurt that endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for a period of twenty days. This includes emasculation, permanent privation of the sight of either eye, permanent privation of the hearing of either ear, the privation of any member or joint or the destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfiguration of the head or face, and fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Diabetic patients with local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discolouration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Risk factors:

  • Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Treatment:

  • Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.
  • Surgical debridement
  • Control of underlying predisposing causes.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of exenatide, that is used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Exenatide is a GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) receptor agonist. It stimulates insulin secretion, inhibits glucagon release, delays gastric emptying, reduces food intake, and normalizes fasting and postprandial insulin secretion. It is given subcutaneously. It can also cause pancreatitis, and therefore is not used in patients with a history or risk of developing pancreatitis.

GLP-1 analogs are peptides and are generally given other than oral routes due to degradation by intestinal peptidases. But semaglutide was synthesized by adding sodium caprylate which increases its permeability and leads to its absorption before it gets degraded. Hence, it enabled oral usage of a GLP-1 analog.

Mechanism of Action: GLP-1 receptor agonists stimulate glucose-dependent insulin secretion from pancreatic β-cells, suppress glucagon secretion from pancreatic α-cells, and delay gastric emptying.

GLP-1 analogs: Exenatide ,Liraglutide ,Albiglutide ,Dulaglutide, Lixisenatide ,Semaglutide

Other options:

Option A: Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or in combination therapy when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated. It binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system. Hence, no dosage adjustment is needed in renal failure.

Option C: Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. It is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold.

Option D: Pramlintide is an islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP) or amylin analog. Amylin analogs reduce glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying, and centrally decrease appetite. 

Related Pearl: Treatment Goals for Adults with Diabetes

Index

Goal

HbA1c*

< 7 %

Preprandial capillary plasma glucose

80–130 mg/dL

Peak postprandial capillary plasma glucose

<180 mg/dL

Blood pressure+

< 140/80 mmHg

*Note that most diabetes associations recommend the target HbA1c must be individualized to the patient. A target of <7% is reasonable in most individuals.

+ Blood pressure: Harrison's 20th  edition,(based on ADA) recommends the target blood pressure goal of <140/90 mmHg for adults with diabetes. It further adds that for younger individuals the target blood pressure is <130/80 mmHg. But the "AHA/SPRINT TRIAL recommendations" recommend that the goal of blood pressure in patients with diabetes mellitus is less than 130/80 mmHg.

Dyslipidemia: Although not a treatment goal, ADA recommends to intensify lifestyle therapy and optimize glycemic control for patients with elevated triglyceride levels (≥150 mg/dL [1.7 mmol/L]) and/or low HDL cholesterol (<40 mg/dL for men, <50 mg/dL  for women). Treatment with statins would depend on the overall cardiovascular risk (ASCVD) rather than specific LDL/HDL cholesterol level.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with complaints of excessive lacrimation. Ocular examination showed an abnormality similar to what is shown below. Which of the following organism is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Herbert's pits. This finding is seen in trachoma which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, more specifically the TRIC (trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis) serovars A, B, Ba, C. 

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage.

The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms). Examination findings at this stage show: 

  • Conjunctival follicles containung Leber cells (multinucleated lymphocytes)
  • corneal Herbert's follicles (similar to conjunctival follicles)

Cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. And when the chronic infection with sequelae sets in, the patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia and later blurring, and finally loss of vision. Conjunctiva shows concretions (whitish deposits of inspissated mucus in depressions called glands of Henle). Corneal signs include: 

  • Herbert pits (pitted scars in the limbal which are remnants of healed of Herbert follicles)
  • corneal opacity is seen in later stages.

There can be associated trichiasis ( when at least one eyelash rubs the eyeball) and entropion.

At present WHO grading with `FISTO’ is in use.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

Strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (1–9 yrs)

  • Prevalence >10% → SAFE
  • 5 to 10% → FE
  • < 5% → NO intervention

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text: In which of the following views is the frontal sinus best assessed?
questions.solution:
Caldwell's view (occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position):

The view is taken with nose and forehead touching the film and X-ray beam is projected 15–20° caudally.

Structures seen are:

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure).

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: A patient presented with yawning, feeling of anxiety, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, increased sweating, and secretions from the eyes and nose were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid withdrawal. 

The features of opioid withdrawal are:

  • Feeling of anxiety
  • Yawning
  • Lacrimation, diaphoresis, rhinorrhea
  • Diffuse myalgias progressing to piloerection
  • Mydriasis
  • Nausea, profuse vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramping

Treatment of opioid withdrawal:

  • Symptoms can be rendered more tolerable by the administration of the central α2-agonist like clonidine
  • Antiemetics and antidiarrheal agents
  • Daily administration of a verified dose of methadone PO is recommended to inhibit withdrawal symptoms and reduce craving

questions.text: Which of the following virus is known as delta virus?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis D is called delta virus. It is a defective RNA virus, which depends on Hepatitis B for its replication. It has no independent existence. Two types of infection may occur:  

  • Co-Infection: Delta virus and HBV are transmitted together at the same time.
  • Super-Infection: Delta viral infection occurs in a person already harbouring the HBV. This leads to chronic hepatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Propylthiouracil can be used in the first trimester of pregnancy. It is indicated in the management of hyperthyroidism.

Other options

ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin receptor blockers are fetopathic and can cause fetal growth retardation and hypoplasia of organs. 

Statins can cause Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of joint pain and progressive loss of joint motion. On examination, symmetric joint swelling of the hands is seen. A subcutaneous nodule is seen over her right forearm. Microscopy of the excised nodule shows the findings given in the image below. Which of the following lab findings will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Uric acid crystals in joint aspirate
Calcium pyrophosphate crystals in joint aspirate

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and microscopy showing necrotizing granuloma in the subcutaneous nodule is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's serum will test positive for rheumatoid factor. 

Microscopy of the excised nodule shows a necrotizing granuloma with a central zone of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by a prominent rim of activated macrophages and numerous lymphocytes and plasma cells.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of autoimmune origin that principally attacks the joints, producing nonsuppurative, proliferative, and inflammatory synovitis. The inflammation progresses to the destruction of the articular cartilage and ankylosis of the joints.

80% of patients have serum IgM or IgA autoantibodies that bind to the Fc portions of their own IgG. These autoantibodies are called rheumatoid factor. Another antibody that is specific for RA is anti-citrullinated peptides (CCPs). 

The characteristic histologic features of RA include: 

  • Synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation
  • Dense inflammatory infiltrates
  • Increased vascularity due to angiogenesis
  • Fibrinopurulent exudate on the synovial and joint surfaces
  • Osteoclastic activity in the underlying bone    

This all together leads to a mass of edematous synovium called pannus, which grows over the articular cartilage and causes its erosion.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, soar throat, and dyspnea. The examination finding of the oral cavity is shown below. What will be the media used to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with pseudomembrane over tonsil is suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria. Loeffler's serum slope is the medium for diagnosis of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

Loeffler's serum slope (shown in the image below) is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is not a selective medium as other organisms can also grow on this medium. Rapid growth occurs within 6-8 hours. Colonies appear at first as small, opaque discs. They increase in size on continued incubation and may acquire a yellow tint.

Corynebacterium diphtheria (also called Klebs-Loeffler bacillus) is a gram-positive bacillus with clubbing at both ends. They possess characteristic polymetaphosphate granules also called metachromatic granules.

Diphtheria is characterized by mild fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, malaise, loss of appetite, and hoarseness (if the larynx is involved). The hallmark is a grey-white pseudomembrane over the mucous lining of the tonsils (most commonly), pharynx, larynx, or nares. It is tightly adherent to the underlying tissue, and any attempt to dislodge the membrane may cause bleeding. 

A few patients develop massive swelling of the tonsils and present with bull-neck diphtheria, due to edema of the submandibular and paratracheal region.

Other options:

Lowenstein-Jenson medium is shown in the given image. It is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture. Malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein Jenson medium a selective media by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Middlebrook’s media is a liquid culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is shown in the image below.

Thayer-Martin medium is shown in the image below. It is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The antimicrobials present in it, suppress the growth of other commensal organisms which may inhibit the growth of N.gonorrhoeae. It contains antimicrobials like vancomycin, colistin, and nystatin in chocolate agar.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with easy fatigability, irritability and inability to concentrate. The bone marrow examination revealed the following findings. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and microscopy showing Gaucher's cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance is suggestive of Gaucher's disease. The deficient enzyme is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase). 

Gaucher's disease is an inborn error of metabolism caused due to a deficiency of beta glucocerebrosidase. It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder and the mode of inheritance is autosomal recessive. There is an accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the spleen, liver, and other tissues.

Typical clinical features include delayed puberty, painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly, liver cirrhosis, hypersplenism and pancytopenia, bleeding tendencies, bone pain due to avascular necrosis, osteoporosis, and pathological fractures

Gaucher's cells - These are formed as a result of the accumulation of massive amounts of glucocerebrosides within the phagocytes. The cells have a fibrillary cytoplasm and give a crumpled tissue paper appearance.

Other Options:

Option A: A deficiency of hexosaminidase A is seen in Tay-Sachs disease. The deficiency of hexosaminidase A and B cause Sandhoff's disease. Clinical features are seizures, macrocephaly, and hyperacusis. 

Option C: Deficiency of sphingomyelinase leads to Niemann-Pick disease. It is characterized by the presence of foam cells in the bone marrow. There may be pulmonary infiltrates leading to lung failure. 

Option D: Deficiency of N-acetylglucosaminidase leads to Sanfillipo's disease. It is a type of mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS - III). There is an accumulation of heparan sulfate leading to severe cognitive degeneration.

questions.text: An elderly chronic smoker is diagnosed with ischemic heart disease and is started on propranolol. After some days, he is brought to the emergency department with a history of difficulty in breathing which he says gets worsened after taking propranolol. The mechanism that is mainly responsible for worsening his breathing difficulty is
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of respiratory difficulty in the patient have worsened after the intake of propranolol. The mechanism that is mainly responsible for worsening his breathing is β2 blockade. Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It blocks the β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle and prevents bronchodilation. Therefore, it should not be given to patients who have asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Other important side effects of beta-blockers are:

  • Cardiovascular system- 
    • Beta blockade decreases myocardial contractility. Therefore, it can exacerbate decompensated heart failure.
    • Decreased heart rate- Bradycardia, In patients with heart block it can cause fatal bradyarrhythmias
    • Abrupt discontinuation of β receptor antagonists after long-term treatment can exacerbate angina
  • Respiratory system- bronchospasm due to blockade of β2 receptors in the bronchial smooth muscles.
  • Central nervous system- fatigue, sleep disturbances, and depression.
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease occurs due to the blockade of β2 receptors in the vascular smooth muscles.
  • It can slow the recovery from insulin-induced hypoglycemia as they inhibit catecholamine-mediated glycogenolysis.
  • This class of drugs is also known to mask the hypoglycemia symptoms in diabetic patients. The symptoms of hypoglycemia which are mediated by the adrenaline release will be masked as beta-blockers will not allow adrenaline to react and interact with its beta 1 receptor.  
  • Hyperkalemia- blockade of β2 receptors prevents the entry of extracellular potassium into the cells.
  • Sexual dysfunction in males
  • They can also alter the serum triglyceride and HDL-cholesterol concentrations. Beta-blockers such as atenolol, metoprolol, and propranolol increase the levels of triglycerides and decrease the levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Other beta-blockers like labetalol, pindolol, and acebutolol do not have any effect on lipid levels.

Autonomic innervation of the lung.

Relaxation of the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles is brought by β2 receptors. Contraction is by the M2 and M3 cholinergic receptors. Therefore, important drugs that used for bronchodilation are 

  • β2 selective agonists like salbutamol, terbutaline, salmeterol, formoterol, etc,
  • Antimuscarinic agents like ipratropium bromide, tiotropium, aclidinium, and umeclidinium.

Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It acts equal affinity to both β1 and β2 receptors. It does not have intrinsic sympathomimetic activity and does not block α receptors.

Important adverse effects of propranolol are:

Cardiovascular system- It can cause or exacerbate heart failure in patients with compensated heart failure, acute myocardial infarction, or cardiomegaly. In patients with partial or complete AV conduction defects, β antagonists may cause life-threatening bradyarrhythmias. Sudden discontinuation of beta-blockers after prolonged use can exacerbate angina and may increase the risk of sudden death.

Respiratory system- It blocks the β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle and can cause bronchospasm.

Nervous system- It causes fatigue, sleep disturbances (including insomnia and nightmares), and depression.

Metabolism- It delays the recovery from insulin-induced hypoglycemia.

Overdosage may lead to hypotension, bradycardia, prolonged AV conduction, and widened QRS complexes, seizures, depression, hypoglycemia, and bronchospasm.

questions.text: A preterm baby in the neonatal intensive care unit is being screened for retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). She is found to have stage 2 ROP in zone I with no plus disease.  What is the recommended treatment for this stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The recommended treatment for ROP stage 2 in zone I (categorized as type I/low-risk ROP) is careful observation and follow-up.

Retinopathy of prematurity occurs in premature infants with low birth weight, with a typical history of exposure to oxygen in high concentrations leading to bilateral proliferative retinopathy. 

Stages of Retinopathy of Prematurity:

  • Stage 1- demarcation line formation at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
  • Stage 2- intraretinal ridge formation
  • Stage 3- ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous.
  • Stage 4- subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5- total retinal detachment
  • 'Plus' disease is characterized by dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels in at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus. It signifies the progression of the disease.

Location:

Zone I: Circular area with a radius twice the distance from disc to the fovea, with the disc as the center. (as shown in the image)
Zone II: It covers the area beyond zone I circumferentially till nasal ora serrata.
Zone III: It consists of residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II.

These zones are shown in the image below:

 

Treatment is based on guidelines set by the early treatment of retinopathy of prematurity trial (ETROP).

Type 1: Treatment within 72 hours (High risk)

  • Any ROP + plus disease
  • Stage 3 ROP in zone I
  • Stage 2/3 in zone II + plus disease.

Type 2: Observation (Low risk)

  • Stage 1/2 in zone I only and no plus disease
  • Stage 3 ROP within zone II and no plus disease.

This can be summarized in the table below:

    Stage 1   Stage 2   Stage 3
Zone I Observation Observation Treatment
Zone II - without plus disease   Observation  Observation
Zone II- with plus disease   Treatment Treatment

 

ROP of any stage in any zone, if associated with 'plus' disease, should receive treatment urgently.

Treatment includes laser ablation of the avascular peripheral retina, anti-VEGF medication (bevacizumab), and pars plana vitrectomy for advanced disease. The high-risk patients requiring treatment should receive it within 72 hours.

questions.text: A 2 years old male child is brought with pellagra like symptoms and cutaneous photosensitivity. The child most likely has__________

choices.text: Branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase deficiency

questions.solution:
The above clinical history of pellagra like symptoms and photosensitivity in a 2 year old child is suggestive of Hartnup disease. Hartnup disease (pellagra like dermatosis) is an autosomal recessive condition caused due to a single defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan and other monoamino monocarboxylic amino acids (neutral amino acids). This results in decreased availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis. Thus, manifesting as pellagra like symptoms.

Clinical features:

  • Most of the children are asymptomatic
  • Symptomatic patients show cutaneous photosensitivity
  • The skin becomes rough and red after moderate exposure to the sun and with greater exposure, a pellagra-like rash may develop. The rash maybe pruritic and chronic eczema may also appear.
  • Some patients may also have an intermittent ataxia, manifested as an unsteady wide based gait, which usually lasts for few days, and recovers spontaneously.

Diagnosis:

  • Urine testing for amino acids.
  • Diagnosis of Hartnup disease is made by showing the characteristic amino acid excretion pattern in urine. Indoles and other tryptophan degradation products in urine provide supplementary evidence of the disease.

Treatment:

  • Niacin or niacinamide supplements
  • Nicotinamide for attacks

Other options:

Option 1: Homogentisate oxidase deficiency causes alkaptonuria. Children present with bluish-black connective tissue, ear cartilage and sclera. and urine turns black on prolonged exposure to air. 

Option 2: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency causes phenylketonuria. Children present with hypopigmentation, eczema, musty body odour and intellectual disability. 

Option 3:

questions.text: Follow-up treatment with which of the following is required in a patient who underwent a valve replacement surgery?
questions.solution:
Oral warfarin anticoagulation is a long-term treatment that is required after heart valve replacement. This treatment can prevent serious complications, such as embolism, thereby increasing patients' postoperative survival rates and quality of life.

Warfarin:

  • Uses of warfarin are acute deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and preventing stroke or systemic embolization in patients with a mechanical heart valve.
  • Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation).
  • The therapeutic dose of warfarin is monitored by an INR range of 2-3. Warfarin toxicity can occur when the INR exceeds 4 and can lead to fatal bleeding. Treatment includes withholding warfarin, with vitamin K, and blood transfusions or fresh frozen plasma to replenish clotting factors.

In patients with mechanical heart valves:

  • The INR ratio recommended for the administration of warfarin in patients with mechanical heart valves is around 2.5-3.5.
  • Warfarin therapy is usually monitored by measuring prothrombin time.
  • Prothrombin time is sensitive to the reduction in levels of prothrombin, factor VII, and factor X.
  • International normalized ratio (INR) was developed to standardize the reporting of prothrombin time.

questions.text: The sodium chloride co-transporter is present in which part of the nephron?

choices.text: Thin descending limb of loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The sodium chloride co-transporter is present in the early distal convoluted tubule (DCT).

Distal convoluted tubule: Approximately 7% of the filtered load of sodium chloride is reabsorbed in the early distal tubule. This occurs due to the presence of sodium chloride co-transporter. Even this segment dilutes the tubular fluid as it is impermeable to water. 

Reabsorption of sodium in different parts of the nephron are:

  • Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT): 
    • Nearly 60% of the filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the PCT. Solutes mainly absorbed in the proximal tubule are sodium, chloride, bicarbonate, phosphate, lactate, glucose, amino acids etc. 
    • In early PCT, the main sodium channels used for reabsorption are Na+-glucose cotransporter (SGLT), Na+-H+ exchanger, Na+-amino acid cotransporter, Na+-phosphate cotransporter, etc. 
    • In distal PCT, due to high chloride concentration in the lumen, it favors NaCl reabsorption, driven by Cl− gradient. 
    • The total solute and water reabsorption are proportional to each other. Thus, the entire proximal tubule also reabsorbs nearly 60% of the filtered water (isosmotic reabsorption). 
  • Loop of Henle:
    • The thin descending limb has no active transport of Na+ outside the lumen but the loop is permeable to water, making the tubular fluid hypertonic.
    • A thick ascending limb reabsorbs nearly 30% of the Na+ by Na–2Cl–K cotransporter, an example of secondary active transport. This loop is impermeable to water. Since some of the solutes are reabsorbed and water is not reabsorbed, it dilutes the tubular fluid. Other ions like Ca 2+, and Mg2+ are also absorbed here. 
  • Distal convoluted tubule: Approximately 7% of the filtered load of sodium chloride is reabsorbed in the early distal tubule. This occurs due to the presence of sodium chloride co-transporter. Even this segment dilutes the tubular fluid as it is impermeable to water. 
  • Cortical collecting tubule: The remaining 3% of the filtered Na+ is absorbed via ENaCs (epithelial sodium channels) in this duct.  This portion is regulated by aldosterone to maintain homeostasis in Na+ balance.

Clinical aspect: 

i) Barrter syndrome is a congenital renal disorder due to mutation in Na–2Cl–K cotransporter, ROMK K+ channel, ClC–Kb Cl− channel, or barttin. It is characterized by chronic urinary Na+ loss, with hypovolemia, hypokalemia, and alkalosis.

ii) Gitelman syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting the sodium chloride co-transporter in the distal tubules, leading to decreased sodium chloride reabsorption. 

iii) Liddle syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder where mutation results in increased activity of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) in the distal and collecting tubules. This leads to increased reabsorption of sodium and water causing hypertension and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: All the following drugs and their response with the receptors are correctly paired, except _______.

choices.text: Graph 4- succinylcholine at Nicotinic ACh Receptor

questions.solution:
All the following statement is correct, except option C. Graph 4 depicts the action of the inverse agonist. Whereas, succinylcholine exhibits agonism at the nicotinic ACh Receptor.

Graph 1 represents the agonist: An agonist is an agent which initiates the normal physiological response when combined with a receptor. Example: Salbutamol is a beta-2 receptor agonist.
 
Graph 2 represents a partial agonist: An agent which produces a submaximal or partial effect when combined with a receptor. Example: Buprenorphine and butorphanol are partial agonists at opioid receptors.
 
Graph 3 represents the competitive antagonist: An agent which blocks or reduces the action of an agonist on a receptor, but does not have any effect of its own. Example: Naltrexone and naloxone are antagonists at opioid receptors.
 
Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist: An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist. Example: β-Carboline is an inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules helps in diapedesis through the endothelium during acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Diapedesis is the movement of leukocytes through the intact endothelium of the capillaries to reach the site of injury. This process is aided by platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1).

The process of acute inflammation has 3 components: An increase in blood flow due to small vessel dilation, and increased permeability of the microvasculature to aid plasma proteins and leukocytes to leave the circulation and migrate to the site of injury to exert their effects.

The recruitment of leukocytes to the site of injury involves the following steps:

  • The lumen of the vessel to the endothelium:

    • Margination and rolling: In response to inflammation, leukocytes undergo margination, where they move to the periphery of the blood vessel, facilitated by weak interactions with selectins expressed on endothelial cells. This causes leukocytes to roll along the vessel wall.

    • Activation and firm adhesion: Chemokines and other inflammatory mediators induce the activation of leukocytes. This leads to the expression of integrins on their surface, such as LFA-1 (lymphocyte function-associated antigen-1). Integrins on leukocytes bind to endothelial adhesion molecules, including ICAM-1 (Intercellular adhesion molecule-1) and VCAM-1 (Vascular cell adhesion molecule-1), leading to firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium.

    • Transendothelial migration: PECAM, expressed both on endothelial cells and leukocytes, plays a crucial role in transendothelial migration. It mediates homophilic interactions between leukocytes and endothelial cells, facilitating the migration of leukocytes across the endothelium. PECAM acts as a bridge between leukocytes and endothelial cells during diapedesis.

Diapedesis occurs through the inter endothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions such as platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1).

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a thyroidectomy for a patient with a multinodular goiter. Damage to which structure is most likely to cause vocal cord paralysis?
questions.solution:
Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve will cause vocal cord paralysis.

All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except for the cricothyroid are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Cricothyroid is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve which is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

Since most of the laryngeal muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, the most appropriate answer would be recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Other options:

  • External laryngeal nerve: It supplies motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for controlling the tension of the vocal cords. Damage to this nerve can cause weakness or paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, leading to changes in voice quality and pitch. 
  • Internal laryngeal nerve: It provides sensory innervation to the larynx above the vocal cords. Damage to this nerve may result in decreased sensation in the upper part of the larynx
  • Superior laryngeal nerve: Similar to the external laryngeal nerve, damage to the superior laryngeal nerve can affect the function of the cricothyroid muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anaemia. Pyridoxine acts as a cofactor for the enzyme aminolevulinate synthase which is involved in Heme synthesis.

Sideroblasts are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing siderotic granules which stain positively with Prussian blue stain. Based on aetiology, sideroblastic anaemia is classified into hereditary and acquired types.

Hereditary sideroblastic anaemia is an X-linked disorder caused due to a defect in the activity of aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthetase required for heme synthesis. Affected females act as carriers while males have moderate to marked anaemia and manifest in childhood or during early adulthood

Acquired sideroblastic anaemia:

I) Primary acquired:

  • Also called idiopathic or refractory acquired sideroblastic anaemia
  • Due to the reduced activity of the enzyme ALA synthetase, there is disturbed growth and maturation of the erythroid precursors at the level of hematopoietic stem cell
  • Moderate to severe anaemia
  • Neutropenia and thrombocytopenia may also be seen
  • Regarded as a myelodysplastic disorder in the FAB classification and thus considered preleukaemic

II) Secondary acquired: Due to

  • Drugs, chemicals and toxins: Isoniazid, Cycloserine, Chloramphenicol, Cyclophosphamide, Alcohol, Lead, etc.,
  • Haematological disorders: myelofibrosis, polycythemia vera, acute leukaemia, myeloma, lymphoma and hemolytic anaemia.
  • Miscellaneous: Carcinoma, myxoedema, rheumatoid arthritis and SLE.

Laboratory findings:

  • Peripheral smear: Hypochromic, microcytic (sometimes normocytic) anaemia
  • Absolute values: MCV, MCH and MCHC are reduced except in the acquired type, where MCV is raised.
  • Bone marrow: Erythroid hyperplasia. Marrow iron stores are raised. Pathognomonic ring sideroblasts are present.
  • Serum ferritin: Raised
  • Serum iron: Raised
  • TIBC: Normal
  • Haemoglobin electrophoresis: Normal

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought with complaints of excessive watering of the eyes and photophobia. On examination, you note the following. Intraocular pressure is measured to be 30mm of Hg. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of excessive watering, photophobia, enlarged eyeballs with a bluish discoloration, and increased IOP suggests a likely diagnosis of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma is a condition characterized by high intraocular pressure that occurs due to a developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber. 

The child presents with lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm. It may also present with buphthalmos. This refers to a large eye that results from stretching due to raised IOP before 3 years of age. The thin sclera appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue. Haab striae (curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane) and corneal haze (due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP) may also be noted on examination. 

Initially, an IOP measurement is performed (10–12 mmHg is normal). A corneal diameter measuring greater than 12 mm is highly suggestive of congenital glaucoma.

Management is essentially surgical and involves either goniotomy and/or trabeculotomy. 

Other options:

Option B: Retinoblastoma presents around 1 - 2 years of age. The most common clinical features are leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and strabismus. 

Option C: Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy presents with visual impairment and corneal clouding due to focal/diffuse thickening of the Descemet membrane.  

Option D: Ehlers–Danlos syndrome type VI (ocular sclerotic form) is an inherited disease of impaired collagen formation. Ocular manifestations are scleral fragility, blue sclera, microcornea, ectopia lentis, myopia, and retinal detachment.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not an adverse effect of ACE inhibitors?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors are associated with the development of hyperkalemia.

Hyperkalemia occurs due to inhibition of angiotensin II action on aldosterone secretion. Decreased aldosterone levels result in decreased tubular excretion of potassium leading to hyperkalemia.

The adverse effects of ACE inhibitors are

  • Hypotension
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Cough
  • Angioedema
  • Skin rash
  • Teratogenicity

questions.text: The school health programs are managed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The school health programs are managed by the primary health centre (PHC).

The School Health Committee (1961) in India recommended that the school health services should be a part of the general health services. Since the general health services are administered through PHCs, school health programs are also managed by the PHCs under their jurisdiction.

The School Health Committee advocated the formation of school health committees at the village level, block level, district level, state level, and national level. The National School Health Council will be an advisory and coordinating body.

PHCs provide the following school health services:

  • Screening of general health assessment of anemia/nutritional status, visual acuity, hearing problem, dental check-up, physical disabilities, learning disorders, and behavior problems, etc.
  • Basic medicines for common ailments
  • Immunization 
  • Micronutrient (Vitamin A, iron, and folic acid) management
  • Deworming 
  • Mid-day meal

 Note: National Programme for Mid-Day Meal in Schools has recently been renamed Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN).

questions.text: The fourth heart sound is caused by:

choices.text: Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Closure of mitral  and tricuspid valves

questions.solution:
The fourth heart sound is caused by ventricular filling. The atrial contraction against the stiff ventricle produces an audible S4 sound

During ventricular filling, the atria contract to push blood into the ventricles. In conditions where the ventricular walls are stiff or hypertrophied, such as in conditions like hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or systemic hypertension, the atrial contraction against the stiff ventricle produces an audible S4 sound.

During the cardiac cycle, there are two main phases: diastole and systole. Diastole is the relaxation phase when the chambers fill with blood, while systole is the contraction phase when the chambers pump blood out.

The fourth heart sound (S4) occurs during diastole, specifically late diastole, just before the first heart sound (S1). It is caused by atrial contraction, which happens as the atria forcefully contract to push the remaining blood into the non-compliant or hypertrophied ventricle.

questions.text: A patient presents to emergency with pinpoint pupil, salivation, lacrimation and tremors. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of organophosphate poisoning.

Organophosphates and carbamates are powerful acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. They bind irreversibly to acetylcholinesterases. 

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhoea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

Nicotinic manifestations include twitching of eyelids, tongue, and facial muscles which then leads to paralysis. CNS stimulation results in headaches, tremors, ataxia, coma, and death. 

Atropine is useful in organophosphate poisoning because it is a competitive antagonist of acetylcholine. An acetylcholinesterase enzyme has an active and anionic site. The organophosphates bind to the active site of AChEs (acetylcholine esterases) and deactivate it. This results in excessive Ach causing muscarinic activity. It has relatively insignificant action on nicotinic receptors. Pralidoxime is used to counter the nicotinic effects of organophosphates. It reactivates the acetylcholinesterase which is been deactivated in organophosphate poisoning. 

Patients who present with organophosphate and carbamate poisoning require early endotracheal intubation to avoid respiratory depression, which is a common complication. Succinylcholine is avoided due to its metabolism by acetylcholinesterase which leads to prolonged neuromuscular blockade. 

Other options:

Option B: Dhatura poisoning results in mydriasis and has almost opposite symptoms.

Option C: Opioid poisoning and pontine haemorrhage result in pinpoint pupils but other symptoms are not characteristic of those conditions 

Option D: In alcohol intoxication, there would be a history of recent ingestion of alcohol. Patients would present with slurred speech, incoordination, unsteady gait, and nystagmus. Impairments in attention and memory are also seen (option d)

questions.text: The image below shows the cross-section of the trachea. Identify the structure marked.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image shows the trachealis muscle. 

The trachea is a tube-like structure that allows air to pass between the larynx and the bronchi.

The trachealis muscle is a smooth muscle located at the posterior wall of the trachea. It connects the ends of the C-shaped tracheal cartilage rings and completes the posterior part of the tracheal wall.

The histological section of the trachea shows the following structures:

  • Respiratory epithelium
  • Basement membrane
  • Submucosal glands (both serous and mucous parts)
  • Perichondrium
  • Tracheal cartilage
  • Trachealis muscle (smooth muscle).

The histological image below is that of the trachea as identified by the presence of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium lining, the serous and mucous glands, and hyaline cartilage.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of passing loose bulky stools that were associated with abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. The stool examination shows the following organism. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and an image showing a pear-shaped / pyriform-shaped trophozoite is suggestive of giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia.

Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is a common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.

Infection occurs by the ingestion of mature cysts in contaminated water and food. and may also be transmitted by the faecal-oral route.

It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.

Clinical features:

  • Diarrhoea 
  • Fat malabsorption
  • Dull epigastric pain
  • Belching and flatulence
  • Iron deficiency and growth stunting.
  • The stool will have excess mucus and fat but no blood.

Detection of antigens by ELISA is more sensitive and specific than microscopy. Entero test /string test is also used in the diagnosis.

Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites. The trophozoite is heart-shaped or pyriform-shaped with 2 equally sized nuclei and 4 pairs of flagella. It exhibits slow oscillating motility that resembles falling leaf motility. 

Other options:

Isospora belli is a coccidian parasite that can cause protracted diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The oocyst is not easily seen on stool-wet mounts. It may be visible after stool concentration and staining with acid-fast stain, as shown below.

Cryptosporidium parvum, commonly causes diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts in the stool can be visualized by modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining. It appears as red acid-fast spheres. It can also be used for specimens such as sputum and bronchial wash. The image given below demonstrates uniformly acid-fast oocysts of Cryptosporidium parvum.

Trichomonas vaginalis is found in the genital tract. The image given below shows the trophozoite of Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: Match the following eggs to the organisms given in the table below.
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

The Hymenolepis nana egg is roughly spherical or ovoid. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore that encloses the hexacanth oncosphere. They are non-bile-stained. The eggs float in the saturated salt solution. 

The image below shows an egg of H. nana.

 

Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm) are round or oval in shape. They are always bile-stained which gives them golden-brown color. The eggs float in a saturated salt solution. They have a thick smooth translucent shell with:

  • an outer coarsely mammillated albuminous coat
  • a thick transparent middle layer, and
  • an inner lipoidal vitelline membrane.

The unfertilized eggs of Ascaris are elliptical, narrower, and contain a small atrophied ovum. It has a mass of disorganized refractile granules. The shell is thinner and the egg does not float in a saturated salt solution

The image below shows the egg of A. lumbricoides.

 

The egg of Ancylostoma duodenale or hookworm is oval or elliptical. They are colorless, not bile-stained. The eggs are surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane. It contains a segmented ovum, usually with 4-8 blastomeres. There is a clear space between the ovum and the shell. It floats in the saturated salt solution. The image below shows the egg of A. duodenale.

 

The eggs of Taenia solium and Taenia saginata are indistinguishable. The egg is spherical. The inner embryophore is radially striated and is yellow-brown due to bile staining. A fully-developed embryo (oncosphere) with three pairs of hooklets (hexacanth embryo) is present in the center.

The eggs of T. saginata are infective only to cattle and not to humans, whereas the eggs of T. solium are infective to pigs and humans. The eggs do not float in a saturated salt solution. The image below shows the egg of Taenia.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: The collagen defective in Alport’s syndrome is
questions.solution:
In Alport’s syndrome, there is a defect in Type IV collagen.

Type IV collagen is an important component in the basement membranes of renal glomeruli, inner ear, and eye. Hence, the main presenting feature of Alport’s syndrome is hematuria, accompanied by ocular lesions-anterior lenticonus and sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: All of the following are duties of a male health worker except?
questions.solution:
All of the options are duties of male health workers except maintenance of eligible couple registers.

The maintenance of eligible couple registers comes under the purview of the female health workers. She is also expected to regularly update it.

Male health workers are responsible for environmental sanitation. This includes chlorination of public water sources such as wells at regular intervals. They are expected to assist the accredited social health activist (ASHA) and other health volunteers in carrying out directly observed therapy, and short-course (DOTS) activities. He also motivates tuberculosis patients to adhere to regular treatment. They also have duties under the Reproductive and Child Health Program (RCH). This includes the distribution of conventional contraceptives to couples. He also helps prospective sterilization acceptors to undergo the procedure.
