questions.text: Identify the nerve passing around the marked structure.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the neck of fibula. The nerve passing around the neck of fibula is the common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve).

The sciatic nerve divides into the tibial nerve and the common fibular nerve. The common peroneal nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the ventral rami of L4, L5, S1, and S2. 

The common fibular nerve runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular head. It then curves laterally around the neck of fibula and gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves.

Superficial fibular nerve:

Motor innervation: 

  • Peroneus longus
  • Peroneus brevis

Sensory innervation: 

  • Lateral aspect of the lower leg
  • Dorsum of the toes except for the lateral side of the 5th toe and the first interdigital webspace

Deep fibular nerve:

Motor innervation:

  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Tibialis anterior
  • Peroneus tertius

Sensory innervation:

  • The first interdigital space

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. Injury results in foot drop (which causes high-stepping gait), loss of eversion of the foot, and sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot.

questions.text: A toddler has been consuming excessive amounts of vitamin A-containing foods in the diet. The child has dry-flaky skin, frequent headaches,  episodic vomiting, and splenomegaly. Which of the following findings would likely be seen on taking an X-ray of the long bones?
questions.solution:
The history of excessive vitamin A consumption along with scaly, itchy skin, headache, vomiting (suggestive of pseudotumor cerebri), and splenomegaly, all point towards a diagnosis of hypervitaminosis A. In this condition, x-ray of the long bones would most likely show hyperostosis.

Hypervitaminosis A refers to the excessive consumption of vitamin A. Amounts greater than 6,000 micrograms per day in children can be toxic. As vitamin A is fat soluble, it cannot be excreted in the urine leading to accumulation in the liver and various other tissues.

This stored vitamin will continue to exert toxic effects on the body, even if consumption is stopped. In young children, hypervitaminosis A can present with headache, vomiting, and even bulging fontanelles. Pseudotumor cerebri (with elevated intracranial pressure), can present with diplopia and even papilledema. There can also be patches of itchy, desquamating skin. Abdominal examination may reveal hepatosplenomegaly.

Bones may show hyperostosis on x-ray. This is an overgrowth of bone, commonly along the middle part of the shafts of long bones. 

Stopping further consumption is the only way to manage this condition.

The image below depicts hyperostosis-

Other options-

Option (A): Salt and pepper sign is seen in the skull in primary hyperparathyroidism. This disorder causes demineralization and resorption of bone, resulting in pathological fractures, bone erosions, etc. 

The image below shows the salt and paper appearance of the skull-

Option (C): Bone cysts can be simple or aneurysmal. They are usually incidental findings on radiographs. Sometimes these cysts can present with pain due to recurrent bleeding or pathological fractures. Bones cysts can sometimes be seen in hyperparathyroidism as well.

The image below depicts a bone cyst in the humerus-

Option (D): Decreased bone density can be seen most commonly in osteoporosis. The most common causes for this decreased bone mineral density are- vitamin D deficiency, gonadal sex steroid deficiency, hyperparathyroidism, decreased bone formation with age, etc.

The image below demonstrates decreased bone density in osteoporosis-

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presented with a nasal mass and intermittent epistaxis. On examination, the mass is reaching up to the cheek and causing a unilateral obstruction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, with these clinical features, most likely has an angiofibroma. 

Angiofibroma, a benign tumor that affects young male patients, is the most common benign tumor of the nasopharynx. It is a histologically benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that grows at the back of the nasal cavity.

  • Origin: It originates from the fibrovascular stroma on the posterolateral wall of the nasal cavity in the area of the sphenopalatine foramen.

A vascular tumor arising from the periosteum with fibrous tissue and blood vessels.

It encroaches by expanding into surrounding areas like the nasal cavity, sphenoidal sinus, pterygopalatine fossa, maxillary sinus, orbit, and cranial cavity.

Clinical Features

    • Blocking of the nose
    • Epistaxis
    • Secondary sexual characters not well developed
    • Rhinolalia clausa
    • Anterior/ posterior rhinoscopy
    • Bulging of soft palate +/-
    • Spread by expansion

Biopsy should not be attempted

Blood supply is most commonly from the internal maxillary artery of that side.

Treatment:

  • Wilson’s transpalatal approach
  • Lateral rhinotomy
  • If intracranial extension
  • Role is doubtful
    • Excision
    • Radiation
    • Hormonal therapy

questions.text: Hitzelberger’s sign is seen in_____
questions.solution:
Hitzelberger’s sign is seen in acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma).

When the tumor affects the sensory fibers of the facial nerve, there will be hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall. This is called Hitzelberger’s sign.

Sensory fibers are affected early, motor fibers are more resistant and are affected late.

questions.text: A camp was organized to screen for hypertension and diabetes. What level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Screening is an example of secondary prevention.

Early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment is the component of secondary prevention. Some examples of secondary prevention are as follows:

  • Papanicolaou (Pap) smear for early detection of cervical cancer
  • Mammography, for early detection of breast cancer
  • Colonoscopies, for early detection of colon cancer
  • Blood Pressure Screening

Secondary prevention measures focus on the sub-clinical stage and the early clinical stage, such as dysplasia in this case. These measures enable early detection and prompt effective intervention at an earlier stage of the disease.

Prevention can be done at 4 levels: primordial, primary, secondary, and tertiary.

Other options:

Option A: Primordial prevention prevents the emergence or development of risk factors in population groups or countries where they have not appeared yet through individual and mass education. For example lifestyle modifications such as eating patterns and physical exercise to prevent obesity in later years.

Option C: Primary prevention includes intervention in the pre-pathogenesis stage of any disease through two strategies. 

  • Mass strategy: Health promotion in the entire population such as sanitation, and infection control.
  • High-risk strategy: Specific protection is given to high-risk groups through means such as immunization, and chemoprophylaxis.

Option D: Tertiary prevention is intervention in the late pathogenesis stage of a disease that has progressed beyond the early stages. It aims to limit impairment, disability and suffering.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a substrate for glucose formation?
questions.solution:
Acetyl coenzyme A (CoA) is not a substrate for glucose formation.

Acetyl CoA and compounds that give rise to acetyl CoA alone like acetoacetate, lysine, and leucine cannot give rise to a net synthesis of glucose. This is because of the irreversible nature of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which converts pyruvate to acetyl CoA. These compounds give rise to ketone bodies instead.

The synthesis of glucose in the body, in the absence of dietary carbohydrates, occurs in two ways:

  • From liver glycogen, by a process known as glycogenolysis in the absence of dietary carbohydrates, for up to 24 hours.
  • De novo, from non-carbohydrate sources, by a process known as gluconeogenesis, when glycogen stores have depleted. This occurs primarily in the liver and to a lesser extent in the kidneys.

In gluconeogenesis, the substrates can be:

  • Oxaloacetate (from its conjugate acid, oxaloacetic acid) is a direct precursor of phosphoenolpyruvate
  • Pyruvate is an α-keto acid that can be converted to glucose.
  • Alanine is a glucogenic amino acid that is transaminated to form pyruvate by the enzyme alanine amino-transferase in the liver.
  • Lactate obtained from anaerobic glycolysis is released from skeletal muscles and RBCs into the blood. This is taken up by the liver in the Cori cycle to be oxidised to pyruvate, to eventually synthesize glucose 
  • Glycerol from adipose tissue is converted to dihydroxyacetone phosphate in the liver, which itself is an intermediate of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.

The steps and enzymes involved in gluconeogenesis are shown in blue in the flowchart below.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with hearing loss for the past 2-3 months and the otoscopic finding is suggestive of serous otitis media. 

The given otoscopic image shows a dull and opaque tympanic membrane with clear effusion.

Serous otitis media is also known as secretory otitis media or mucoid otitis media or glue ear. It is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft. 

Glue ear is thought to happen due to either malfunctioning (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx) or increased secretory activity of the eustachian tube (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections).

It is often seen in children 5-8 years of age. They present with hearing loss not exceeding 40 dB, which is insidious in onset. Speech may be delayed and defective due to hearing loss. Mild earaches with a history of upper respiratory tract infection are usually seen. 

On otoscopy, 

  • Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex
  • Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus 
  • If the tympanic membrane is transparent fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen

 The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss. X-ray mastoid reveals clouding of air cells. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. 

  • Medical management includes decongestants, antihistamines, antibiotics, and middle ear aeration techniques. 
  • Surgical management includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid, grommet insertion, tympanotomy, or cortical mastoidectomy.

Other options: 

Option A: Myringitis bullosa is characterized by painful hemorrhagic blebs on the tympanic membrane and deep meatus. It occurs due to infection by a virus or mycoplasma. 

Option C: Acute otitis media is an acute infection of the middle ear by pyogenic organisms. It presents with marked earache and hearing loss is seen in later stages. Otoscopy shows a red and bulging tympanic membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a paranasal sinus?
questions.solution:
Pyriform sinus (fossa) is a part of hypopharynx. It lies on either side of the larynx and extends from pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of oesophagus.

Sinuses are air-containing cavities in certain bones of skull.

It is divided into 2 groups.

Anterior group includes

  • Maxillary
  • Frontal
  • Anterior ethmoidal sinuses.

Posterior group includes

  • Posterior ethmoid
  • Sphenoid sinuses.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady is diagnosed with Hashimoto thyroiditis. She has antibodies against the thyroid peroxidase enzyme. Which of the following function is not affected by this enzyme?
questions.solution:
Iodide trapping (iodide uptake) is not catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. It occurs with the help of an iodide pump.

Thyroid peroxidase catalyses oxidation, organification(iodination) and coupling.

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

  • Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) actively takes up I-(iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. It is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter 
  • Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by follicular cells.
  • Iodination of thyroglobulin: The process of incorporating iodine into the tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin, leading to the formation of iodothyronine. This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 
    • Oxidation: TPO oxidizes I- to I2 (iodine)  in the presence of H2O2
    • Organification: TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)
    • Coupling reactions: TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)
  • Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months
  • Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is taken up by the thyroid follicles via endocytosis and fuses with lysosomes. It is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes into MIT, DIT, T3, and T4. T4 (80%) and T3 (20%) are released into the blood
  • Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone

questions.text: Transport of lipid-soluble substances across the cell membrane occurs via which of the following?
questions.solution:
Lipid-soluble substances are transported across the cell membrane via diffusion.

Passive diffusion is a process by which a lipid-soluble molecule is able to freely cross in and out of the cell by dissolving itself in the phospholipid bilayer.

Other options:

  • Option A: Exocytosis is a process by which cells actively release substances from their intracellular compartments to the extracellular space. It involves the fusion of vesicles with the cell membrane to release their contents. 

  • Option B: Endocytosis is a process by which cells take in substances from the extracellular space into the cell by forming vesicles at the cell membrane.

  • Option C: Osmosis is the movement of water molecules across a semipermeable membrane in response to differences in solute concentration.

Related Pearl: Transport across the cell membrane

questions.text: Analysis expressing results of health care benefits in terms of results achieved, like the number of lives saved, instead of monetary benefit is called ______________
questions.solution:
Cost-effective analysis: The benefits of the health care system are expressed in terms of results achieved (Eg: the number of lives saved or the number of days free from disease). This is a more promising tool in the application in the health field than cost-benefit analysis. However, even cost-effective analysis is not possible in many cases.

other options:

Cost-benefit analysis: The economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to determine whether a given program is economically sound and to select the best out of several alternate programs. The main drawback of this technique is that the benefits in the health field, as a result of a particular program, cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. We generally express the benefit in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome.

Input-output analysis: How much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, "input" refers to all health service activities which consume resources (manpower, money, materials and time); and "output" refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

Network analysis: A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Management Methods in Health Programmes:

Methods based on behavioral sciences

Quantitative methods

Organisational design

Personnel management

Communication

Information systems

Management by objectives(MBO)

Cost–Benefit analysis

Cost-Effective analysis

Cost–Accounting

Input–Output analysis

Model

Systems analysis

Network analysis- Includes Programme Evaluation and Review Technique(PERT) and Critical Path Method(CPM)

Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)

Work sampling

Decision making

questions.text:
Match the following cell types with their associated malignancy.
1. Popcorn cell a. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
2. Faggot cell b. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
3. Cerebriform nuclei c. Burkitt lymphoma
4. Starry sky d. Sezary syndrome
questions.solution:
The correct matches are 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c.

1. Popcorn cell b. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
2. Faggot cell a. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
3. Cerebriform nuclei d. Sezary syndrome
4. Starry sky c. Burkitt lymphoma

 

Popcorn cell is a lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant of Reed Steenberg (RS) cells that are characteristic of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma. It has a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus resembling popped corn. The image below shows a popcorn cell seen in lymphocytic predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks are known as faggot cells and are highly suggestive of acute promyelocytic leukemia. Histopathology from bone marrow aspirate reveals numerous Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes. Faggot cells are shown below.


Mycosis fungoides is cutaneous T cell lymphoma which usually stays confined to the skin. It can disseminate into blood which is known as Sezary syndrome.  Histological hallmark includes:

  • Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters.
  • Epidermotropism - invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis.
  • Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane).

The image shows sezary cells with cerebriform nuclei in the peripheral smear.


Microscopy in Burkitt lymphoma shows a characteristic starry sky pattern. The neoplastic cells are homogeneous, medium-sized B cells with frequent mitotic figures and reactive macrophages scattered through the tumor, with their pale cytoplasm in a background of blue-staining tumor cells giving the tumor a so-called "starry sky" appearance.

The image given below shows a starry sky pattern seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

dermatofibroma

questions.text: What does the “a” wave in JVP represent?
questions.solution:
The "a" wave in JVP represents atrial contraction.

Waves of JVP :

  • a- Atrial systole pushing the blood to the ventricles.
  • c- Isovolumetric contraction of ventricles causing the tricuspid valve to bulge.
  • x- Fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to the pull of valve leaflets.
  • v- Venous filling which creates an increase in atrial pressure.
  • y- Passive filling of ventricles by a passive flow of blood from the right atrium.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

questions.text: A 12-month-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever and difficulty in breathing. On examination, the child had biphasic stridor. The lesion in which of the following level will produce this type of stridor?
questions.solution:
Obstructive lesions at the level of glottis, subglottis (B), and cervical trachea will cause Biphasic stridor.

Stridor is a noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with a fever and weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. A bone marrow biopsy is obtained later and is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with bone marrow histology showing lymphoblasts (condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm) is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. 

ALL is more common in childhood. Clinical features of ALL include:

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is ___
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of breathing difficulty and unsuccessful attempts of extubation after total thyroidectomy is suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury is often acute. Neuritis or surgical trauma (thyroidectomy) are the most important causes. All the intrinsic muscles are paralyzed in this condition. The vocal cords lie in the median or paramedian position due to the unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles. This leads to dyspnoea and stridor but the voice is good.

Tracheostomy is done as an emergency procedure. Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:

  • Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation) - it involves excising laterally the soft tissue at the junction of membranous cord and vocal process of arytenoid with laser.
  • Partial arytenoidectomy - it involves excision of the medial part of the arytenoid with laser.
  • Reinnervation procedures - these are used to innervate paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.
  • Thyroplasty type II - it creates lateral expansion of larynx.

questions.text: A 19-year-old athlete presented with pain, numbness and fatigue of the right arm. Angiography revealed decreased blood supply through the blood vessels anastomosing near the surgical neck of the humerus. The thrombus is likely to be present  in:
questions.solution:
The thrombus is likely to be present in the third part of the axillary artery.

The anterior and posterior circumflex humeral arteries, which are branches of 3rd part of the axillary artery, anastomose at the surgical neck of the humerus.

Branches of 3rd part of axillary artery are:

  • Anterior circumflex humeral arteries
  • Posterior circumflex humeral arteries
  • Subscapular artery (not involved in the anastomosis)

Clinical significance:

  • Fracture of surgical neck: It is the commonest site among all proximal humerus fractures due to its inherent weakness. Fracture at this site may cause injury to the posterior circumflex humeral artery and the axillary nerve that accompanies it.
  • Positional compression of axillary artery: In some athletes who are involved with throwing movement, as in baseball players, repeated movement of the humerus may cause compression of the distal part of the axillary artery. This may lead to thrombosis or aneurysm resulting in arm ischemia.

questions.text: Which type of FSGS has the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
The collapsing variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) has the worst prognosis.

There are 5 variants of FSGS: 

  • Collapsing variant (poor prognosis)
  • Glomerular tip variant (good prognosis)
  • Cellular variant
  • Perihilar variant
  • Not otherwise specified variant (most common)

Below is a histological image of collapsing glomerulopathy showing the involvement of the entire glomerular tuft and the proliferation of visceral epithelial cells.

questions.text: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) affects CD4 cells due to interaction of the protein  __________
questions.solution:
The CD4 cells are affected by HIV due to their interaction with gp120.

Structure of HIV:

HIV-1 virion is spherical and contains an electron-dense, cone-shaped core surrounded by a lipid envelope derived from the host cell membrane.

The virus core contains (1) the major capsid protein p24; (2) nucleocapsid protein p7/p9; (3) two copies of viral genomic RNA; and (4) the three viral enzymes (protease, reverse transcriptase, and integrase). The viral core is surrounded by a matrix protein called p17, which lies underneath the virion envelope.

The viral envelope is studded by two viral glycoproteins, gp120 and gp41, which are critical for HIV infection of cells.

Pathogenesis:

  • Target cells of HIV: include CD4+ helper T cells (worst affected), monocyte-macrophages, and dendritic cells.
  • Viral glycoprotein gp120 binds to CD4+ cells in the host.
  • This binding leads to a conformational change causing exposure of a new recognition site gp41 for the co-receptors.
  • CXCR4 and CCR5 function as coreceptors for HIV-1 entry into CD4+ cells.
  • The virus then fuses with the host cell membrane.
  • gp41: Fusion peptide at the tip inserts into the cell membrane of the target cells (e.g., T cells or macrophages), leading to the fusion of the virus with the host cell.

questions.text: A patient presenting with chronic gout has been prescribed a drug that inhibits xanthine oxidase.  Which among the following drugs is it?
questions.solution:
Febuxostat is a selective inhibitor of xanthine oxidase thereby reducing xanthine and uric acid. 

Allopurinol and febuxostat are xanthine oxidase inhibitors indicated in the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients suffering from gout. Febuxostat is more potent than allopurinol. 

The adverse effects include hepatotoxicity, diarrhea, joint pain, and rash. A flare in the gout attack can be seen during the initiation of therapy due to a decrease in serum uric acid levels that results in the mobilization of uric acid from tissue deposits.

Other options:

Option A: Colchicine is an antimitotic drug that is used in the treatment of acute gout. It acts by inhibiting microtubule and spindle formation. Side effects are nausea, vomiting, myelosuppression, aplastic anemia, and rhabdomyolysis.

Option B: Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acids by inhibiting the organic anion transporter, particularly URAT-1 in the renal tubule. It is used to decrease the body pool of urate in patients with chronic gout. It is used as an adjuvant to allopurinol in chronic gout and hyperuricemia. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation.

Option C: Pegloticase and rasburicase catalyze the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin. This product is soluble and inactive. It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated.

questions.text: A man was stuck inside a building that caught fire. He died of suffocation due to smoke. Which of the following postmortem changes is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The person died of suffocation due to smoke. This indicates carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning which will cause cherry red postmortem hypostasis.

Victims of smoke inhalation are affected by carbon monoxide poisoning. Carbon monoxide has a higher affinity to haemoglobin as compared to oxygen and hence the amount of haemoglobin available for oxygen transport is markedly reduced. It can cause anaemic hypoxia. The binding of CO to haemoglobin results in cherry red discolouration.

Other options:

Option A- Mummification requires high temperature and strong air currents. As there were no air currents in this situation, mummification is unlikely.

Option B- Pugilistic attitude is seen when muscle proteins are coagulated at high temperatures. Since this person did not die of burn injuries, a pugilistic attitude will not be seen.

Option D- Rigor mortis is not delayed. On the contrary, it may have rapid onset because of heat.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Early diagnosis and treatment is the best level of prevention of breast cancer. It is a secondary level of prevention.

The earlier a disease is diagnosed and treated, the better is the prognosis. The occurrence of secondary cases or any long term disability can be prevented. This is of particular importance in chronic diseases.

Early diagnosis and treatment is not as effective and economical as primary prevention. However, it may be critically important in reducing the high morbidity and mortality in diseases such as essential hypertension, cancer cervix and breast cancer.

questions.text: Drug of choice for the treatment of digoxin induced ventricular arrythmia is ?
questions.solution:
Lignocaine has the least effect on AV nodal conduction and is the most appropriate drug for the treatment of digoxin-induced arrhythmias.

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside with a narrow therapeutic index and is used in the management of heart failure.

Mechanism of action: It inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump in the myocardium leading to increased accumulation of intracellular sodium. Increased intracellular sodium prevents the efflux of calcium ions. This results in increased intracellular calcium which increases the contractility of the muscle.

It can also cause bradycardia via its vagotonic and sympatholytic activity.

Clinical features of digoxin toxicity:

CNS manifestations - Drowsiness, neuralgia, headache, confusion or giddiness

Ophthalmic manifestations - Visual aberration is an early indication of digitalis toxicity. Yellow-green distortion is most common. Yellow halos around lights (xanthopsia) is seen. Visual acuity is reduced.

Gastrointestinal manifestations- Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, diarrhea, abdominal pain.

Cardiac manifestations - Palpitations, dyspnea, syncope, hypotension. The most serious side effect of digoxin is arrhythmia. They can present as extreme bradycardia, atrial fibrillation, ventricular extrasystoles, bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and fibrillation.

Digoxin should be discontinued whenever toxicity is suspected. An effective antidote for digoxin toxicity is digibind, which is an antidigoxin antibody. Arrhythmias should be treated 

Other options:

Option A: Procainamide and other class IA anti-arrhythmic agents are not indicated in digoxin toxicity because of their inhibitory effects on AV nodal conduction.

Option C: Atropine is used for atrial bradyarrhythmias associated with digoxin toxicity.

Option D: Propranolol is used for atrial tachyarrhythmias associated with digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the immunization programme?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a ten-year-old schoolchild will be administered the TT/Td vaccine according to the National Immunization Schedule.

The Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. The MoHFW recommends the replacement of TT vaccine with Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

Scheduled to be administered at 10 and 16 years of age.

For pregnant women :

  • Td-1: early in pregnancy
  • Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1
  • Td (Booster): if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

Other options:

Option A - According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG should be given at birth or as early as possible up to 1 year of age. It provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB. A dose of 0.1 ml is administered intradermally in the left upper arm.

Option B - Measles/MR is given at 9 completed months (1st dose) and a second dose is given at 16-24 months. Measles can be given till 5 years of age. A dose of 0.5ml is administered subcutaneously in the right upper arm.

Option D - DPT vaccine is administered as a part of the pentavalent vaccine at the 6th, 10th and 14th weeks of life. DPT booster doses are administered at 16-24 months (first booster) and 5-6 years (second booster). It can be administered until 7 years of age (with booster doses). A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the anterolateral aspect of the mid-thigh. The 2nd booster dose can be administered in the upper arm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the pupillary reflex pathway?
questions.solution:
Medial geniculate body is not a part of the pupillary reflex pathway.

Pupillary light reflex pathway:

  • First neurons (sensory) connects each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculi.
  • Second neurons (internuncial) connects each pretectal nucleus to both Edinger–Westphal nuclei.
  • Third neurons (preganglionic motor) connects the Edinger–Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion.
  • Fourth neurons (postganglionic motor) leaves the ciliary ganglion and passes in the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae.

Image: Pupillary reflex pathways

questions.text: Therapeutic index is used for assessing which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of the drug administered.

Therapeutic index = TD50/ED50 

  • TD50 (Median toxic dose) = Dose required to produce a toxic effect in 50% of animals tested.
  • ED50 (Median effect dose) = Dose required to produce a therapeutic effect in 50% of the individuals.

Option B: Efficacy is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug. It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug.

Option C: Potency refers to the concentration (EC50) or dose (ED50) required to produce 50% of maximum effect where EC50 is the concentration of agonist resulting in a half-maximal response.

Option D: Median toxic dose is the dose required to produce a toxic effect in 50% of animals tested. Lethal dose is the dose required to kill 50% of animals tested.

questions.text: During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon is making an attempt to identify the Calot’s triangle. All of the following identified by the surgeon are the boundaries of the Calot's triangle, except ____.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves and arteries pass beneath the extensor retinaculum of the foot?

choices.text: Deep peroneal nerve, Posterior tibial artery
Superficial peroneal nerve, Posterior tibial artery
Deep peroneal nerve, Anterior tibial artery
Superficial peroneal nerve, Anterior tibial artery

questions.solution:
The nerves and arteries pass beneath the extensor retinaculum of the foot are deep peroneal nerve and anterior tibial artery.

The following are the structures passing deep to the superior and inferior extensor retinacula:

  • Tibialis anterior tendon
  • Extensor hallucis longus tendon
  • Deep peroneal nerve
  • Extensor digitorum longus tendon
  • Peroneus tertius tendon

The anterior tibial vessels pass deep to the superior extensor retinaculum, while the dorsalis pedis vessels pass deep to the inferior extensor retinaculum.

Note: The tendon of tibialis posterior passes deep to the flexor retinaculum of the foot

questions.text: An epidemiologist is assessing an outbreak of acute diarrhoeal disease in a region. He wants to predict the virulence of the causative agent. Which of the following parameters will he use for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate is used in this scenario as it is the most useful parameter to predict the virulence of an acute illness. It represents the killing power of disease.

Note:

Case fatality rate is an incidence proportion and not a true rate as no time interval is used for its calculation.

 

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy had persistent headaches,  gait disturbances and cognitive difficulties. CT scan revealed a cystic mass in the right cerebellar hemisphere which was resected. The biopsy of the specimen showed cells with long, hairlike processes that stained positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and histopathological findings showing cells with long hair-like processes positive for GFAP are suggestive of pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a benign (grade I) astrocytoma that typi­cally occurs in children and young adults. It is usually located in the cerebellum, optic nerves, brainstem and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres.

They can present with symptoms like headaches, gait disturbances, and cognitive and personality changes. These symptoms may be a result of increased intracranial pressure due to tumour enlargement or edema which may result in hydrocephalus. Seizures usually occur in cases of metastasis. 

The imaging method of choice is cranial MRI with gadolinium contrast. It reveals a cystic and well-demarcated mass.

The tumour is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin hair-like processes that are glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)-positive and form dense fibrillary meshwork. Rosenthal fibres (eosinophilic corkscrew-shaped inclusions) and eosinophilic granular bodies (mulberry-like inclusions) are characteristic findings. It has biphasic architecture, with both loose microcystic and compact fibrillary areas.

These tumours grow very slowly with limited brain invasion and can be treated by resection alone. The image below shows the histopathology of pilocytic astrocytoma, with characteristic bipolar cells with long hair-like processes.

 

Hemangioblastoma is a fluid-filled cystic lesion that typically arises in the cerebellum and in the retina. Histology would show stromal cells and abundant vessels. It may be associated with polycythemia and von Hippel-Lindau disease.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding nitric oxide?
questions.solution:
Nitric oxide acts by increasing cGMP not by increasing cAMP.

Nitric Oxide

  • Also known as Endothelium-derived relaxing factor (EDRF).
  • Synthesized in endothelial cells from arginine in a reaction catalyzed by nitric oxide synthase (NOS).
  • Mechanism of action:
    NO causes activation of guanylyl cyclase → ↑ cGMP → relaxation of vascular smooth muscle → vasodilation.
  • Effects of NO:
    • Vasodilation.
    • Neuromodulator in brain.
    • Antimicrobial and cytotoxic activity of various inflammatory cells.
    • In GIT, relaxation of smooth muscle.
    • Penile erection.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules, which implies retinitis pigmentosa (RP).  

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common, and among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry: Initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

There is no effective treatment for RP.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the dermatology OPD with a history of itchy hypopigmented patches over her chest for 6 months. A KOH mount is prepared with the skin scraping sample, which on microscopy reveals a characteristic appearance as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the KOH mount preparation showing the spaghetti and meatball appearance suggest pityriasis versicolor.

Pityriasis Versicolor is a chronic superficial infection of the stratum corneum caused by Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur. The most common site involves the neck, chest, back, and upper arms. The lesions often appear as hypopigmented areas.

The KOH mount reveals fungal hyphae that are short and thick (like spaghetti or banana) and many variously sized spores (like meatballs or grapes) referred to as spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance.

Treatment includes topical azoles or terbinafine for 2 weeks.

The image below shows the hypopigmented lesions of P. versicolor over the chest.

Electron microscopic image of Malassezia furfur

questions.text: A patient presented with painless, hard swelling in the upper eyelid away from the lid margin, which has been progressing in size.  The curettage specimen subjected to histopathological evaluation showed a lipogranulamatous lesion. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of a progressive, hard, painless swelling away from the lid margin, is due to a probable diagnosis of chalazion.

A chalazion is a chronic and non-infective lipogranulamatous lesion that arises from the Meibomian glands (otherwise known as a tarsal/meibomian cyst). It is the most common lid swelling seen. The upper eyelid is more commonly involved than the lower eyelid because the upper eyelid has more meibomian glands. 

Patients present with painless swelling away from the lid margin, watering of the eyes, blurring of vision, and blepharitis. 

Histopathology shows a lipogranulamatous picture with extracellular fat deposits surrounded by lipid-laden epithelioid cells.

Below attached is an image of the chalazion:

A very small, soft, and recent chalazion only requires conservative management with hot compresses and topical antibiotic drops. Incision and curettage is the more conventional method of managing a chalazion. The contents are curetted out using a chalazion scoop. Intralesional steroids such as triamcinolone are preferred for chalazion which are located where the risk of surgical damage is greater (near structures such as lacrimal punctum).

A chalazion may become infected and form a hordeolum internum. Also, a recurrently forming chalazion should be biopsied to rule out meibomian gland adenocarcinoma (a form of sebaceous cell carcinoma).

Other options: 

Option A: Hordeolum externum is the suppurative inflammation of the gland of Zeis. It is hard and painful, and there is a visible pus point on the lid margin. 

Below attached is an image of a patient with hordeolum externum:

 

Option B: Hordeolum internum is the suppurative inflammation of the Meibomian gland and may occur as a primary infection or secondary to infected chalazion. There is a tender swelling with the pus point facing toward the tarsal conjunctiva. The below image shows an internal hordeolum.

 

Option D: Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection (poxvirus) and forms multiple, pale and umbilicated swellings scattered over the lid margin.

Below attached is an image of a patient with molluscum contagiosum:

questions.text: A sexually active male patient presented to the Suraksha clinic with complaints of urethral discharge and burning micturition. The patient was prescribed the kit shown in the image below. Which of the following antibiotic combinations are present in this kit?

choices.text: Inj. Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units and azithromycin 1 gram

questions.solution:
The grey kit provided by the Suraksha clinics contains a combination of azithromycin 1 gram(single dose) and cefixime 400 mg(single dose).

The grey kit is prescribed to patients with complaints of urethral discharge and burning micturition. This kit is also prescribed to all recent sexual partners of the patient.

The national aids control organization (NACO) provides treatment for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) through specialized clinics known as Suraksha clinics. Color-coded drug kits are supplied to these clinics for the management of STIs.

questions.text: A young male patient presented with pain and stiffness in the neck following an accident. On examination, the right shoulder is drooping and he has difficulty shrugging his shoulder. Which of the following muscles is likely to be paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is indicative of paralysis of the trapezius muscle.

The trapezius is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). It causes: 

  • Retraction of scapula
  • Shrugging of the shoulder
  • Overhead abduction (along with serratus anterior)

Paralysis of the trapezius causes drooping of the shoulder and slight winging of the scapula (the superior angle of the scapula becomes more prominent).

Nerves causing winging of the scapula:

Nerves Muscles Type of winging
Spinal accessory nerve

Trapezius

 The superior angle of the scapula becomes more prominent (lateral winging)
Long thoracic nerve

Serratus anterior

 The scapula is pulled upwards and towards the spine by the unopposed action of the trapezius (medial winging)
Dorsal scapular nerve Rhomboid major, and rhomboid minor Similar to serratus anterior but mild winging

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following causes Keshan's disease?
questions.solution:
Keshan disease is due to a deficiency of selenium.

Selenium is an important trace element which is a part of the 21st amino acid Selenocysteine. There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as :

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant which complements the role of Vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, meat, and some cereals.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Dilated cardiomyopathy is the characteristic feature, but it may also result in congestive cardiac failure, cardiomegaly, and fulminant cardiogenic shock. It is associated with tumorigenesis (increased risk of progression to metaplasia) and atherosclerosis.

Other options:

Option A: Thiamine deficiency leads to Beri-beri and Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome.

Option C: Zinc deficiency causes acrodermatitis enteropathica. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhoea, recurrent infections, alopecia, and neurological manifestations like tremors, nystagmus, irritability, and night blindness. Skin changes include vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities, perianal and perioral regions. Chronic zinc deficiency can cause stunted growth, decreased taste sensation(hypogeusia), impaired immune function and hypogonadism, and hypopigmented hair.

Option D: Copper deficiency can present as anemia, cardiovascular defects including aneurysms, hypopigmentation, and neurological symptoms such as ataxia.

questions.text: An adolescent boy presents with yellowish discoloration of sclera. His liver function tests reveal conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normal liver enzyme levels. Liver biopsy revealed an accumulation of dark melanin like pigment in the hepatocytes. What is the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with dark pigment deposition (image below) in the liver. These features are suggestive of Dubin Johnson syndrome.

In Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS) there is defective excretion of conjugated bilirubin and various compounds like epinephrine metabolites causing the liver to appear black.

Rotor syndrome also has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but there is no pigmentation of the liver.

Gilbert and Crigler-Najjar syndromes are characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Related Pearl: Rotor syndrome vs Dubin johnson syndrome

  Rotor syndrome Dubin Johnson syndrome
Inheritance Autosomal recessive Autosomal recessive
Defect Organic anion transporting polypeptide  defect.(OATP1B1,OATP1B3) Multi drug resistance protein (MRP )2 mutation
Biopsy Normal Black pigmentation
Conjugated bilirubin Elevated Elevated
Kernicterus absent absent

questions.text: A 54-year-old farmer from Ohio presents to a physician with a chronic cough. A chest X-ray demonstrates a mass lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of the mass and staining with lactophenol cotton blue  demonstrates multiple, tiny yeast forms within macrophages as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the presence of tiny yeast forms within macrophages are suggestive of Histoplasmosis.

Histoplasmosis is also known as Darling's disease, Cave's disease or Ohio disease. It is endemic in USA i.e. it has specific geographical distribution.

The causative agent is Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus. It is a facultative intracellular parasite. Yeast form occurs mainly in tissues at a temperature of 37oC and mycelial form occurs in soil at 25oC. Spores are found in bird or bat droppings in the soil which acts as reservoir of infection. Transmission occurs via inhalation of conidia. Person-to-person transmission or animal-to-man transmission is not yet known.

After inhalation, the conidia develop into yeast cells and are engulfed by alveolar macrophages. Within macrophages, the yeasts may disseminate to reticuloendothelial tissues, such as the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and lymph nodes. Biopsy reveals tiny (2-4 microns) oval-shaped yeast cells inside macrophages.

On culture and microscopy, tuberculate macroconidia and hyaline septate mould with microconidia are seen.

Itraconazole is the treatment for mild to moderate infection, while in disseminated disease, systemic treatment with amphotericin B may be required.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in order of the demographic cycle.

1. Early expanding population

2. Declining population

3. Low stationary population 

4. Late expanding population

5. High stationary population
questions.solution:
The correct order according to the demographic cycle is high stationary population (5) --> early expanding population  (1) --> late expanding population (4) --> low stationary population (3) -->  declining population  (2).

The demographic cycle has 5 stages:

  • Stage 1: High stationary population 
  • Stage 2: Early expanding population 
  • Stage 3: Late expanding population 
  • Stage 4: Low stationary population 
  • Stage 5: Declining population

In a high stationary population, there is a high birth rate and a high death rate that cancel each other and the population remains stationary.

The early expanding population is marked by a decline in the death rate but the birth rate stays constant. Many countries in South Asia and Africa are in this phase. 

In the late expanding population there is a further fall in the death rate, with the birth rate beginning to fall. The population is still increasing due to a net increase in births. India has entered this phase. 

A low stationary population is characterized by low birth and low death rate, and this can result in a stationary population. It has occurred in most industrialized countries as a demographic transition shifting from high birth and high death rates to low birth and low death rates.

A declining population is one where the birth rate is lower than the death rate, causing population decline. Examples include East European countries like Germany and Hungary.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: The probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period is known as the ________.
questions.solution:
The probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period is known as the secondary attack rate.

The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period.

It is calculated by the formula:

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of close or exposed contacts that are susceptible)

Primary cases are usually excluded from the numerator and denominator. The secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease.

Other options:

Option B: Case fatality rate (CFR) is the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a disease who die from it, reflecting the severity of the condition. It is calculated by dividing the number of deaths by the number of diagnosed cases and multiplying by 100.

Option C: Primary attack rate measures the proportion of people who develop a disease after exposure to an infectious agent. It reflects the spread and initial impact of the disease within a susceptible population.

Option D: Tertiary attack rate refers to the spread of disease among contacts of secondary cases, highlighting further transmission within a population. It helps assess the extent of ongoing transmission beyond initial exposure.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

Incidence rate = ( Number of new cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time ) x 1000

Incidence rate of spells of sickness = ( Number of spells of sickness starting in a specified period /Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time ) x 1000

Attack rate = ( Number of new cases of a disease in a specified period of time /Total population at risk during the given time ) x 100

Secondary attack rate = ( Number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of the incubation period/Total number of exposed or susceptible contacts ) x 100

Prevalence = ( Number of all cases (new+old) of a specified disease at a given point in time/ Estimated population at the same point in time ) x 100

questions.text: The most appropriate treatment for motion sickness for a trip next morning is

choices.text: Ranitidine one night before and then before trip

questions.solution:
Scopolamine(Hyoscine) patch is the most appropriate treatment for motion sickness for a trip the next morning. It should be applied for about 5-6 hours before the journey. It should be applied behind the ear. It gives protection for around 72 hours against motion sickness. It is also used in narcoanalysis as it causes sedation and amnesia.

Dimenhydrinate is a first-generation antihistamine that can also be used in motion sickness (Option D). Although dimenhydrinate may have equal efficacy it is not preferred because of it's sedating properties.

questions.text: The most important antigen-presenting cells are ______.
questions.solution:
Dendritic cells are the most important antigen-presenting cells. They initiate T-cell responses against protein antigens.

They are located in the epithelium and interstitium. They express many receptors including toll-like receptors (TLRs) and lectins for capturing and responding to antigens. They also express high levels of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) for presenting antigens and activating T cells.

In response to microbes, dendritic cells are recruited to the T-cell zones of lymphoid organs. Here, they present antigens to T cells with help of MHC. 

Similar cells with dendritic morphology in the germinal centers of lymphoid follicles in the spleen and lymph nodes are follicular dendritic cells. They bear Fc receptors for IgG and receptors for C3b. Immature dendritic cells within the epidermis are called Langerhans cells.

Note:

  • Aggretope - part of the antigen associated with the MHC molecule on the antigen-presenting cell
  • Epitope - antigenic part of contact with the T-cell receptor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the dose-response curve shown in the image below?

choices.text: Drug C is a competitive antagonist
Drug C is more potent than drug A
Drug B is more potent than drug A
Drug B is a competitive antagonist

questions.solution:
In the above image, drug B is a competitive antagonist.

In competitive antagonism, the dose-response curve (DRC) is shifted to the right whereas in non-competitive antagonism the DRC is flattened.

Thus in the above image Drug B is the competitive antagonist while drug C is the non-competitive antagonist.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency.
  • Thus, in the above image, the potency is drug A > drug C > drug B.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is drug A = drug B > drug C.
