questions.text: The following picture shows the composition of solute in the urine and plasma sample of 3 patients. Identify the true statement.

choices.text: A shows negative free water clearance, B is isotonic, C is positive free water clearance
A shows positive free water clearance B is isotonic C is positive free water clearance
A shows positive free water clearance B is isotonic C is negative free water clearance
A shows negative free water clearance B is isotonic C is negative free water clearance

questions.solution:
Patient A shows positive free water clearance, B isotonic and C shows negative free water clearance.

Free water clearance is defined as the amount of solute-free water generated by the kidneys, when dilute or concentrated urine is being formed.

Patient A has positive free-water clearance since excess water is being excreted (dilute urine).

Patient B has a similar concentration of plasma and urine, making them isotonic fluids in this patient.

Patient C has negative free-water clearance since excess solutes are being removed and water is being conserved (concentrated urine).

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with weakness of the left upper limb. On examination, the blood pressure recorded on the left upper limb was found to be lower than that of the right upper limb. Her aortic arch angiogram showed narrowing of the arch of the aorta and subclavian artery. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiological findings are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. It involves the arch of the aorta and its branches, usually the subclavian artery, leading to reduced blood pressure and weak pulse in the affected upper limb.

Takayasu arteritis is a chronic inflammatory medium- and large-vessel vasculitis that commonly affects adolescents and young females. It mainly involves the aortic arch and its branches. Depending on the artery occluded, patients present with the following symptoms:

  • Subclavian artery (most common) - pain, numbness, claudication, and weak or absent radial pulses on the affected side
  • Common carotid artery - visual symptoms, syncope, and stroke
  • Abdominal aorta, superior mesenteric artery, and coeliac axis - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
  • Renal artery - hypertension and renal failure
  • Aortic arch or root - aortic insufficiency, heart failure
  • Pulmonary artery - atypical chest pain, dyspnea
  • Coronary artery - chest pain, myocardial infarction
  • Iliac artery - Leg claudication, weak/absent pulses in the periphery

Patients also have constitutional symptoms such as malaise, fever, night sweats, weight loss, etc.

Lab reports reveal an elevated ESR level, anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels. Arteriography is done as a confirmatory test.

Treatment includes glucocorticoid therapy, methotrexate, immunotherapy with anti-TNF agents, and surgery of the stenosed vessels.

Other options:

Option A: Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

Option C: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN. The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Nerve involvement results in mononeuritis multiplex. Depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:

Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, subcutaneous nodules, and livedo reticularis
Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure
Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation

Option D: Kawasaki disease is an acute self-limiting illness affecting medium-sized arteries in children less than 4 years of age. Coronary arteries are affected which may cause aneurysm, thrombosis or myocardial infarction.

questions.text: Identify the organism & the stain used from the image given below :
questions.solution:
The given image shows Helicobacter pylori under Warthin-Starry stain.

H.pylori is a gram-negative motile rod with lophotrichous flagella. The gastric antrum is the commonest site of colonization. Infection is confined to the gastric mucosa in the stomach or in areas of gastric metaplasia and heteroplasia in the duodenum. 

In some patients, H.pylori causes mild acute gastritis lasting for about two weeks. In others, it can cause peptic ulcer disease which in later stages may lead to chronic atrophic gastritis. This is a risk factor for gastric malignancies like adenocarcinoma and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphomas. 

The urea breath test is a rapid diagnostic procedure used to identify infection, as H.pylori has a unique feature of the production of urease.

The given image shows H.pylori on gastric mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain. The bacteria are present only in the mucus overlying the gastric mucosa and do not actually invade the mucosa.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains These include Eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, Congo red, etc. and are mostly used to stain pathological specimens.
Basic stains.

1.    Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in counterstaining in quellung reaction of streptococcus pneumoniae.  

2.    Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction of anthrax bacilli
Neutral stains

1.    Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

2.    Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and some other spirochete and protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contains more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: Used to distinguish cells by cell-wall type. To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain: Used to distinguish acid-fast bacteria from non-acid-fast cells. Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid – fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Used for rapid scanning of the smear, where the AFB appear fluorescent green against a black background Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "Chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (Anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–Starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor White Staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain Calcofluor white, which greatly enhances visibility of fungal element in tissue or other specimens. It is especially useful for the identification of Mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.   It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For Cell wall demonstration

questions.text: You are studying the optics of a patient with regular astigmatism. Identify the point at which the clearest image is formed?
questions.solution:
The given figure is a Sturm's conoid. It represents a bundle of light rays formed by a regularly astigmatic surface. The image is clearest or least confusing as point D, the circle of least confusion. 

When light passes through a regularly astigmatic surface(surface with toric curvature), vertical and horizontal rays converge at different points.

The distance between the points of convergence (focus) of the vertical and horizontal rays is called the focal interval of strum. (distance between points B and F). The circle of least confusion/ circle of diffusion lies at the mid-point of this interval.

For the given Sturm's conoid, 

  • At point A, a horizontal oval is formed because vertical rays converge more rapidly than horizontal rays.
  • At point B, vertical rays come to a focus, while horizontal rays are still converging; so, it will be a horizontal straight line.
  • At points C, D, and E, the vertical rays are diverging and horizontal rays are still converging.
  • At point D, the vertical rays have diverged as much as the horizontal rays have converged; so, we get a perfect circle called the circle of least confusion.
  • At point E, a vertical oval is formed.
  • At point F, a vertical straight line is formed
  • At point G and beyond, both rays are diverging, and we always get a vertical oval/prolate ellipse.

Astigmatism is a type of refractive error in which the eye does not focus light evenly on the retina. This results in a distorted or blurred vision. Other symptoms include eyestrain or asthenopia with headaches.

Types:

  • Regular astigmatism: In this refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another resulting in 2 principal meridians
  • Iregular astigmatism: It is characterized by an irregular change of refractive power in different meridians and hence it has multiple meridians.

Types of regular astigmatism:

With the rule astigmatism: The vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal meridian but they are placed at right angles to one another

Against-the-rule astigmatism: Here Horizontal meridians is more curved than the vertical meridian

Oblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not the horizontal and vertical meridians although they are at right angles to each other. It is a type of regular astigmatism. eg : one may be at 45 degrees and the other at 135 degrees.

Bioblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other; for example, one may be at 40 degrees and the other, at 100 degrees. It is also a type of regular astigmatism.

Note: Refractive types of regular astigmatism:

  • Simple astigmatism: rays are focused on the retina in one meridian: either in front (simple myopic as shown in the above image) of the retina or behind the retina (simple hyperopic)
  • Compound astigmatism: rays in both the meridia are focused in front or behind the retina
  • Mixed astigmatism: Light rays in one meridian are focused in front of the retina and those in the other meridian are focused behind the retina

questions.text: A patient presented with features suggestive of acute interstitial nephritis. A microscopy of his urinary casts is shown below. These casts are most likely those of _____.
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is having features of acute interstitial nephritis (AIN). So, the casts shown are most likely those of white blood cell casts.

AIN usually occurs as an allergic response to certain medications. The most common offending agents are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. It can also occur with proton pump inhibitors, sulfonamide derivatives and sulfasalazine. 

Individuals with AIN are usually asymptomatic and are incidentally found to have elevated creatinine.  However, in some instances, they can develop fever and rash. In severe cases, renal failure with proteinuria can occur. 

Laboratory studies may show peripheral eosinophilia and urinary eosinophilia. The urinalysis usually shows pyuria and occasionally eosinophiluria. But the most characteristic cell types are activated T lymphocytes and plasma cells, along with a few white blood cell casts. 

Other options: 

Option A: Broad casts are seen in chronic renal failure.

Option B: Hyaline casts may be seen normally and are non-specific.

Option D: Red blood cell casts are seen in acute glomerulonephritis.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman has completed her 1st antenatal visit under the maternal and child health program (MCH). Now she is 14 weeks pregnant. How many more antenatal visits does she need to complete to fulfill the minimum requirement for antenatal visits under the MCH?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the lady should complete 3 more visits to fulfill the minimum requirement of antenatal visits under MCH.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

It is advised that the woman should visit the medical officer at the PHC for an antenatal check-up during 3rd visit.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO (not MCH), is 8.

The ideal number of antenatal visits a mother should take to the antenatal clinic is:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the next month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text: Microanuerysms are seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Among the following microaneurysms are seen in diabetic retinopathy.

Microaneurysms are localized, saccular outpouchings of the capillary wall that are formed either by focal dilatation of the capillary wall where pericytes are absent or by fusion of two arms of a capillary loop.

  • Most develop in the inner capillary plexus (inner nuclear layer), frequently adjacent to areas of capillary non-perfusion.
  • Loss of pericytes may also lead to endothelial cell proliferation with the formation of ‘cellular’ microaneurysms.
  • Microaneurysms may leak plasma constituents into the retina as a result of a breakdown in the blood-retinal barrier or may thrombose.
  • They tend to be the earliest sign of DR.

Stages and fundus picture in diabetic retinopathy:

Non-proliferative/ Background Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • Microaneurysms 
  • Dot and Blot hemorrhages 
  • Exudates

Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (indicates progressive retinal ischemia):

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • NeoVascularization of the Optic Disc (NVD)
  • NeoVascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of the fundus (NVE)

Advanced Diabetic Eye Disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A patient has profuse bleeding after the removal of an IV cannula. He underwent a small bowel resection and was given broad-spectrum antibiotics during his hospital stay. His lab investigations show an elevated prothrombin time (PT). The deficiency of which of the following vitamins is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of vitamin K is responsible for this condition.

Vitamin K deficiency in adults may be seen in patients with chronic small-intestinal diseases like celiac disease, Crohn’s disease, obstructed biliary tracts, and after small-bowel resection. Additionally, broad-spectrum antibiotics can precipitate Vitamin K deficiency by reducing the number of gut bacteria, which synthesize menaquinones.

It is a fat-soluble vitamin that has two natural forms: Vitamin K1, also known as phylloquinone, from vegetable sources, and vitamin K2, or menaquinones, which are synthesized by bacterial flora and found in hepatic tissue.

Vitamin K is required for the posttranslational carboxylation of glutamic acid, which is necessary for calcium binding to γ-carboxylated proteins such as

  • prothrombin (factor II)
  • factors VII, IX, and X
  • protein C, protein S

Patients with vitamin K deficiency usually present with a history of bleeding either at venipuncture sites or minor trauma.

It is diagnosed on the basis of an elevated prothrombin time or reduced clotting factors. It is treated with supplementation by oral or IV route.

Other options:

Option A: Riboflavin or Vitamin B2 deficiency manifests as angular stomatitis, magenta tongue, seborrhea, corneal vascularization. It is seen in alcoholism, and individuals with a poor diet and decreased intake of dairy products.

Option B: Vitamin E deficiency manifests as peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar ataxia, skeletal muscle atrophy, and retinopathy. Usually seen with fat malabsorption or genetic abnormalities of vitamin E metabolism.

Option C: Niacin deficiency manifests as pellagra, which includes symptoms of diarrhea, a pigmented rash over sun-exposed areas, bright red tongue, memory loss, and altered sensorium. Alcoholism, vitamin B6 deficiency, riboflavin, and tryptophan deficiencies predispose to this condition.

questions.text: Visual field testing of a patient revealed bilateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. What is the likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Bilateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing occurs due to the lesion in the occipital lobe.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a  history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets.  Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to iron toxicity, which is managed with deferoxamine (also known as desferrioxamine).

Large amounts of ferrous salts can be fatal in children. Initial symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding. In severe cases, cyanosis and hyperventilation due to metabolic acidosis can develop. This can sometimes be followed by an asymptomatic phase. Later, hypoglycemia and hepatic and renal failure can develop. Pyloric stenosis and gastric scarring can develop due to its corrosive nature. Ultimately, if left untreated, the child can die.

The gastric contents can be used for an iron color test to estimate the iron concentration in plasma. As iron tablets are radiopaque, an X-ray can be used to assess the number of pills taken. Deferoxamine, an iron chelator has to be administered intramuscularly. Side effects include pruritus, wheals, rash, and anaphylaxis. 

Deferiprone and deferasirox are other oral iron chelators used to treat iron overload in thalassemia patients. 

Other options:

Option B: Activated charcoal can be used in the initial management of acetaminophen and opioid overdose. It is used for gastrointestinal decontamination to prevent further absorption of the poison.

Option C: Dimercaprol, also known as BAL (British anti-Lewisite), is used to treat arsenic, mercury poisoning, and Wilson's disease.

Option D: D-penicillamine (Cuprimine) can be used to treat scleroderma, Wilson's disease, and rheumatoid arthritis. Side effects include nephrotoxicity, hematologic derangements, and a characteristic rash that involves the neck and axillae—elastosis perforans serpiginosa. It is associated with membranous glomerulonephritis, drug-induced lupus, and myasthenia gravis.

Related Pearl: Specific antidotes for poisoning

questions.text: Which among the following does not attach to the first rib?
questions.solution:
Among the following scalenus posterior muscle does not attach to the first rib. It attaches to the second rib.

The attachments on the 1st rib are:

  • Subclavius
  • Scalenus anterior
  • Scalenus medius
  • First digitation of serratus anterior
  • Suprapleural membrane
  • Costoclavicular ligament

The scalenus anterior and scalenus medius muscles are attached to the first rib. The scalenus anterior muscle originates from the anterior tubercles of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae and inserts on the scalene tubercle of the first rib. The scalenus medius muscle originates from the posterior tubercles of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae and inserts on the first rib, usually between the attachments of the scalenus anterior and posterior muscles.

questions.text: Rise in which of the following antibody in serum is indicative of recent infection?
questions.solution:
IgM antibody in serum appears early and is indicative of recent infection.

IgG appears late in the serum and is indicative of chronic infection.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text:
Which of the following are essential fatty acids?
  1. Linoleic acid
  2. γ-Linolenic acid
  3. α-Linolenic acid
  4. Oleic acid
questions.solution:
Linoleic acid and α-Linolenic acid are essential fatty acid.

Essential fatty acid refers to polyunsaturated fatty acids required for biological processes but is not synthesized by the body.

The two essential fatty acids in humans are as follows:

  • Linoleic acid (Omega 6): It is the precursor of arachidonic acid
  • α-Linolenic acid (Omega 3): It is the precursor of eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid.

Arachidonic acid and γ-Linolenic acid are semi-essential fatty acids since they can be derived from essential fatty acids.

questions.text: Which type of anaemia is seen in vitamin B12 deficiency?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12 deficiency presents with macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia.

Megaloblastic anemia is a type of macrocytic anemia with impaired nucleic acid metabolism. Nuclear maturation lags behind cytoplasmic maturation. The causes include:

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Folate deficiency
  • Drugs (Methotrexate)

Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Other causes of B12 deficiency includes

  • Malabsorption (Pernicious anemia)
  • Total or partial gastrectomy
  • Ileal resection
  • Tropical sprue

Clinical features of cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency (megaloblastic anemia) include:

  • Anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation
  • Oral manifestations: glossitis, angular cheilosis
  • Mild fever in more severely anemic patients
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Bruising (thrombocytopenia) and infections (low leucocyte count)
  • Complications in pregnancy: recurrent fetal loss and neural tube defects
  • Cardiovascular disease: cerebrovascular, peripheral vascular, and coronary heart disease with deep vein thrombosis
  • Neurologic manifestations: Bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord (SACDSC). Seen in only B12 deficiency.
  • Psychiatric disturbances

Other features of ineffective erythropoiesis seen in megaloblastic anemias include:

  • Howell-Jolly bodies: Nuclear remnants within red cells that are usually single, round, dark purple-red in color, and peripheral in location.

 

  • Basophilic stippling: Blue granules of various sizes dispersed throughout the cytoplasm of the red cell, they represent ribosomal precipitates.
  • Cabot rings: Red cell inclusions appearing as fine, purple filamentous loops or figures of eight forms, presumed to be remnants of mitotic spindles.

The image below shows basophilic stippling and Cabot rings:

questions.text: Haase’s rule estimates the age of foetus from ______
questions.solution:
Rule of Haase enables the estimation of the age of the foetus in lunar months from it's crown-heel length (in cm).

According to the rule,

Age in months = Square root of crown heel length ; when the crown heel length is 25 cm or less.

Age in months = crown heel length divided by 5 ; when the crown heel length is more than 25 cm. 

Note : Haase’s modification of Morrison‘s law states that during last 5 months, the length in centimetres divided by 5 gives the age in months.

Eg : crown heel length = 30 cm, gestaional age = 6 months.

questions.text: A newborn presents with hypoplasia of the mandibles and zygomatic bones, malformed external ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. An abnormality in the development of which pharyngeal arch is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Treacher Collins syndrome that results from abnormal development of the 1st pharyngeal arch (mandibular arch). 

First arch syndromes are congenital defects caused due to the failure of the neural crest cells to migrate into the 1st pharyngeal arch. They are:

Treacher Collins syndrome (mandibulofacial dysostosis) - Autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by:

  • Craniofacial bone defects - Involves mandible, maxilla, and zygomatic arches, causing micrognathia.
  • Ear defects - Involves the external ear, atresia of auditory canals, and abnormalities of the middle ear ossicles leading to bilateral conductive hearing loss
  • Eye defects - Down-slanting palpebral fissures and lower eyelid colobomas

Pierre Robin sequence (or Robin sequence) - Caused due to genetic defects or due to environmental factors. It can also be seen in oligohydramnios when the chin gets compressed against the chest in utero. 

  • It is characterized by a triad of micrognathia, glossoptosis (posteriorly placed tongue), and cleft palate.
  • The primary defect is poor growth of the mandible (micrognathia). As a consequence of this, the tongue is posteriorly placed (glossoptosis), Additionally, the tongue remains in between the palatal shelves and they fail to fuse (cleft palate)

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Branchial Apparatus

questions.text: A young male presents with reduced sleep, hyperactivity, and elevated mood. He has a history of depression from 4 years back. Which of the following drug should be used for long-term treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of depression, with the current symptoms of mania suggests bipolar disorder. Lithium is a mood stabilizer that is used in the treatment of acute mania and bipolar disorder.

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index and hence frequent monitoring of serum lithium concentration is necessary for patients who are on lithium therapy.

0.5-0.8 mEq/L is considered ideal for maintenance therapy in patients with bipolar disorder whereas a serum lithium concentration of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L is required in patients with episodes of acute mania.

Initially, lithium toxicity presents with symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, mild diarrhea, and fine tremors. Nervous system toxicity manifests as coarse tremors, ataxia, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, confusion, slurred speech, and hyperreflexia.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A bodybuilder who does strenuous exercises went to the doctor with complaints of muscle cramps. Muscle cramps are due to the accumulation of lactic acid. Which of the following cycles is responsible for preventing lactate accumulation in the muscle?
questions.solution:
Cori's cycle is responsible for preventing lactate accumulation in the muscle.

The lactate formed in the muscles is converted into glucose by Cori's cycle. Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after anaerobic glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and erythrocytes. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into pyruvate which can be converted to glucose. This entire process is called Cori’s cycle or the glucose–lactate cycle.

Lactic acid which accumulates in the muscle after strenuous muscle exercises enter Cori's cycle. This process prevents the accumulation of lactate thereby preventing muscle cramps.

Other options

Option A- Cahill cycle is also called as glucose–alanine cycle. In the fasting state, there is a significant output of alanine from muscle as it is the major substrate for gluconeogenesis. Alanine is then exported to the liver where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis.

Option C- Krebs cycle, also known as the citric acid cycle, is the final common oxidative pathway that oxidizes acetyl CoA to CO2. It is the source of reduced co-enzymes that provide the substrate for the respiratory chain. It also acts as the link between catabolic and anabolic pathways (amphibolic role).

Option D- The urea cycle is also known as the ornithine cycle. It forms urea by detoxifying ammonia in the liver. The overall reaction may be summarized as NH3 + CO2 + Aspartate → Urea + Fumarate.

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: You notice the following finding while administering OPV for a child. Which of the following nerves does not provide sensory supply to the structure involved?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a cleft palate. The sensory supply to the palate is not provided by the hypoglossal nerve. It is a pure motor nerve.

General sensation from most of the soft palate is carried by:

  1. Lesser palatine nerve (a branch of the maxillary nerve)
  2. Pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve
  3. Plexus around the tonsil (formed by tonsillar branches of the glossopharyngeal and lesser palatine nerves)

Taste sensation from the oral surface of the soft palate is carried by the lesser palatine nerve. The taste fibers initially travel in the greater petrosal nerve (a branch of the facial nerve) and pass through the pterygopalatine ganglion without synapsing.

All the muscles of the soft palate are supplied by the pharyngeal plexus (CN X), except for tensor veli palatini, which is supplied by the mandibular nerve.

The hard palate is supplied by the greater palatine and nasopalatine branches of the pterygopalatine ganglion.

questions.text: Cardiotoxicity is an adverse effect of which of the following anti-cancer drugs?
questions.solution:
Cardiotoxicity is a unique adverse effect of doxorubicin. It is an anthracycline group of anticancer antibiotics.

Anthracyclines:

They work by interacting with DNA directly and affecting transcription and replication. They have the potential to create free radicals which cause irreversible cardiotoxicity and cardiomyopathy which is dose-dependent.

Adverse effects:

  • Cardiomyopathy is the most common adverse effect and it can be either acute, in the form of myocardial damage("pericarditis-myocarditis syndrome"), or a chronic form of dose-dependent cardiomyopathy leading to heart failure.
  • Alopecia, anemia, amenorrhea, leukopenia, nausea, vomiting.
  • Mucositis, diarrhea, thrombocytopenia.
  • Less common: acute lymphoid leukemia,acute myelogenous leukemia,atrioventricular block,esophagitis,hyperpigmentation,myelodysplastic syndrome

Anthracycline-induced cardiomyopathy takes two forms:

  • Acute: pericarditis-myocarditis syndrome, arrhythmias, ST and T wave changes in ECG.
  • Chronic: dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A female patient presented with nausea, vomiting and dizziness. She has been taking medication for an amebiasis infection. She was at a party with her friends and had some alcoholic drinks before the symptoms started. The doctors suspect an interaction between alcohol and the anti-amoebic drug she was taking. What could the drug be?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably having a disulfiram-like reaction, which can occur when metronidazole interacts with alcohol. 

Disulfiram is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor and is used in disulfiram aversion therapy to reduce alcohol dependence. If alcohol is ingested after taking disulfiram, there is an increase in blood acetaldehyde concentration that causes symptoms such as flushing, burning sensation, vomiting, perspiration, tightness of chest, dizziness, throbbing headache, visual disturbance, etc. Knowledge of this may help the patient to resist drinking.

Disulfiram-like reaction is the same reaction mentioned above that has been noted in patients who take the following drugs with alcohol:

  • Metronidazole
  • Sulfonylureas
  • Cefoperazone
  • Procarbazine
  • Griseofulvin

questions.text: The number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births is called ___.
questions.solution:
Maternal mortality ratio is defined as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births during a given time period.

Other options:

Infant mortality rate (IMR) is defined as the ratio of infant deaths registered in a given year to the total number of live births in the same year.

Maternal mortality rate is the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women of reproductive age in a given time period.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

  • Maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.
  • MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 (or 1000)/Number of live births in the same period
  • Main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia related complications, etc.
  • In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: Mutation in which of the following genes causes Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Wilson's disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene. It an autosomal recessive condition.

The ATP7B gene is located on chromosome 13q. The gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions:

  • Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin
  • Helps excrete free copper in bile.

The resulting ATP7B deficiency leads to reduced bound copper and impaired free copper excretion. This causes excess deposition of free copper in the tissues, particularly in the liver, brain and eye.

Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive condition leading to impaired absorption of copper and subsequent copper deficiency. Here, the mutation is in the ATP7A gene.

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections deals with McNaughton's rule?
questions.solution:
IPC section 84 deals with McNaughten’s rule.

McNaughten’s rule:

  • It was formed by the Judges of McNaughten’s case, to clarify the common law of insanity in England during 1843. It is similar to IPC 84 that states “Nothing is offence which is done by a person who at the time of doing it by reason of unsoundness of mind is incapable of knowing the nature of act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law”.
  • This form the basis of the ‘test’ of insanity that the jury should be instructed to apply in each case of alleged insanity.
  • The rules are:
    • Every man is presumed to be sane and to possess a sufficient degree of reason to be responsible for his crimes, until the contrary be proved to their satisfaction.
    • To establish an insanity defence, it must be clearly proved that, at the time of the committing of the act, the accused was laboring under ‘such a defect of reason, from a disease of the mind, as not to know the nature and quality of the act he was doing; or if he did know it, that he did not know he was doing what was wrong’.

McNaughten’s rule now comes under Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023.

Related Pearl: Criminal Responsibilities

BNS Section

Previous IPC Section

Deals with

18

-

A person is not liable for an accident in doing a lawful act

20

82

Child under 7 years is not liable for act.

21

83

Child of 7–12 years if not attained proper mental maturity is not liable for act.

22

84  -McNaughten's rule

A person of unsound mind is not liable for act.

23

85

A person who under involuntary intoxication has commited an act is not liable for the act.

24

86

A person who under voluntary intoxication commits an act is liable for the act.

Related Pearl: IPC Sec 84, McNaughten's rule

McNaughten's rule, Section 84 IPC:  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

It states that an accused is not criminally responsible if he was suffering from:

  • Defect of reason and unsoundness of mind: the law recognizes only those diseases which impair the thinking abilities of the mind. So, not all medically insane people are legally insane, as emotional disturbances that affect the mind are not considered if they do not directly affect cognition.
  • That he did not know the nature and the quality of the act he is doing:  the law needs the unsoundness of mind to exist at the time of the act to such a degree that the person is not aware of what he is doing and whether it is right or wrong to do. Absence of a motive or forethought is also considered as a criteria for determining unsoundness of mind.

McNaughten’s rule now comes under Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023.

questions.text: 4-8 speakers talk about a specific topic in front of a large audience. There is no particular agenda, set speech, or order of speaking. In the end, there is interaction with the audience.  What is this mode of communication best known as?

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. His CT and endoscopy findings are shown in the below image. What could be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
On the basis of the given images, inverted papilloma could be the most likely underlying cause.

Inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumor or transitional cell papilloma or Schneiderian papilloma) is a benign neoplasm of the non-olfactory mucosa of the nose (also called the Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses.

The lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus is the most common site of origin. The hyperplastic papillomatous tissue grows into the stroma.
It is common in the 4th to 7th decades of life with a male preponderance. It is almost always unilateral and presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. It can invade sinuses or the orbit, the latter of which causes proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation.
 
On examination of nose or endoscopy, it presents as a polypoidal mass resembling simple nasal polyps, as depicted by arrows in the endoscopic image above. A computed tomography(CT) scan and/or magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) show the location and extent of the lesion. MRI provides additional help to differentiate associated secretions in the sinus from the actual tumor mass. A biopsy is essential for diagnosis.
 
Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice, done preferably via endoscopy. Recurrence is common and malignancy has been observed in up to 15% of the cases.
 
Other options:
 
Option B: Carcinoma maxilla arises from the lining of the maxillary sinus and its early features include additional symptoms like facial paraesthesias, pain, or epiphora and depending on the direction of spread of the growth, would cause additional symptoms.
 
Option C: Esthesioneuroblastoma (olfactory neuroblastoma) arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nose. It has bimodal peaks of incidence at 10–20 years and 50–60 years. Unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis are the most common symptoms. The tumour also invades the orbit and the surrounding structures, which results in other symptoms like proptosis, headache, epiphora, diplopia, and blurred vision.
 
Option D: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is seen almost exclusively in males in the age group of 10–20 years and is very rarely seen in older people and females. Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis is the most common presentation.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows a school of fish or Railroad track appearance of Haemophilus ducreyi. The pathognomonic school of fish is seen if the bacilli are arranged in small groups, whorls or chains. 

Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STD) that is caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi, a Gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with chancroid/soft sore which is characterized by painful non-indurated, tender, irregular ulcers with enlarged painful and tender lymph nodes that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called "kissing ulcers".

The diagnosis is made clinically and can be supported by the gram stain findings. Treatment is recommended with a single dose of azithromycin (1g oral) or ceftriaxone (250mg intramuscular).

Chancroid has gained clinical significance because it can increase the risk of HIV transmission. Hence, it is important to identify and treat these patients and to inform their sexual partners.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient presents with ptosis, diplopia, and progressive muscular weakness towards the end of the day. She is found to have antibodies against acetylcholine receptors. The given clinical condition is an example of _______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is highly suggestive of myasthenia gravis and it is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease that is usually associated with autoantibodies directed against acetylcholine receptors. In Type II hypersensitivity, antibodies that react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

Antibodies that react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
  • Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
  • Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
  • Pemphigus vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
  • Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
  • Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor)

Antibodies can coat (opsonize) cells, with or without complement proteins, and target these cells for phagocytosis
  • Transfusion reactions
  • Erythroblastosis fetalis
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura

Antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
  • Goodpasture syndrome
  • Vasculitis due to ANCA
  • Acute rheumatic fever
  • Vascular rejection in organ grafts

TSH: Thyroid stimulating hormone

ANCA: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody

questions.text: What does the 'two-cell—two-gonadotropin' hypothesis refer to?

choices.text: FSH and LH inhibits the release of estrogen and progesterone
FSH acts on granulosa cells and LH on theca cells
FSH stimulates estrogen while LH inhibits estrogen
FSH feedback inhibits hypothalamus while LH feedback inhibits pituitary

questions.solution:
Two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis refers to FSH acts on granulosa cells and LH on theca cells.

The two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis is a concept that explains the coordinated actions of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) in the ovary during the menstrual cycle. According to this hypothesis:

  1. FSH acts on the granulosa cells within the ovarian follicles. Granulosa cells are located in the follicles and are responsible for producing estrogen. FSH stimulates the granulosa cells to grow, multiply, and convert androgens into estrogen.

  2. LH acts on the theca cells within the ovarian follicles. Theca cells are located outside the follicles and are involved in the production of androgens. LH stimulates the theca cells to produce androgens, which are then transported to the granulosa cells to be converted into estrogen.

This coordinated action of FSH on granulosa cells and LH on theca cells is necessary for the development and maturation of ovarian follicles, as well as the production of estrogen. It is an important process in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and ovulation.

questions.text: Increased BMR is seen in _____
questions.solution:
Increased basal metabolic rate (BMR) is seen in Cachexia.

BMR is the energy required by an awake individual during rest. It is the minimum energy required to carry out vital functions of the body such as respiration, circulation, etc. It is dependent on the individual's weight, age, and gender.

Cachexia is a metabolic syndrome related to underlying illness and characterized by muscle mass loss with or without fat loss. In this condition, there is considerably more loss of body protein although protein synthesis is not affected.

In cachexia, the continuous release of cytokines in response to infections and cancer increases the catabolism of tissue protein by the ATP-dependent ubiquitin-proteasome pathway, thereby increasing energy expenditure. This leads to a considerable increase in the BMR.

Related Pearl: Basal Metabolic Rate

questions.text: Epithelioid granulomas are not seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Epithelioid granulomas are not seen in  Kikuchi's lymphadenitis.

Histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis also called Kikuchi’s disease is a disease associated with lymphadenopathy. It does not contain any type of granuloma.

Granuloma formation occurs to contain an offending agent that is difficult to eradicate. The activated macrophages may develop abundant cytoplasm and begin to resemble epithelial cells and are called epithelioid cells. Some activated macrophages may fuse, forming multinucleate giant cells.

Common conditions characterized by epithelioid granuloma formation:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Sarcoidosis (non-caseating granuloma)
  • Brucellosis
  • Cat scratch disease (stellate-shaped or round granuloma)
  • Syphilis (gumma )
  • Lymphogranuloma inguinale
  • Leprosy
  • Inflammatory bowel disease 
  • Toxoplasmosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the hospital with complaints of difficulty breathing. Chest X-Ray shows "eggshell" calcification. Histopathology of the lung shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's X-ray and histopathology showing silicotic nodule are suggestive of silicosis.

Silicosis is due to the inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in sandblasting or rock mining

In simple silicosis, the chest X-ray shows small rounded opacities in the upper lobes. When there is progressive nodular fibrosis, irregular masses >1 cm are seen, referred to as complicated silicosis. When these masses enlarge further, it is called progressive massive fibrosis (PMF). Calcification of hilar lymph nodes leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification

Silicotic nodules are characterized by coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibres surrounded by a peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages as shown below.

Silicosis increases the risk of lung cancer. It also increases susceptibility to tuberculosis as pulmonary macrophages are inhibited from killing the phagocytosed mycobacteria by crystalline silica.

Other options:

Option B: Asbestosis shows ferruginous bodies on histopathology

Option C: Lung hamartomas appear as well as circumcised nodules/masses. They do not show silicotic nodules in histopathology.

Option D: Tuberculosis presents with cavitary lesions in the upper lobes of the lungs. Histopathology reveals caseous necrosis with multinucleated giant cells.

questions.text: What is the location of the complexes shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows the electron transport chain (ETC) which is located on the inner mitochondrial membrane. 

The electron transport chain (ETC) is a specialized set of electron carriers that can accept electrons. Energy-rich molecules like glucose are oxidized to produce water and carbon dioxide. The intermediate substrates in these reactions can pass on electrons to certain coenzymes like nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2).

The energy from electron transfer is used to move H+ through the inner mitochondrial membrane. The H+ gradient thus produced results in the production of ATP. ATP synthesis together with electron transport is known as oxidative phosphorylation. 

Option B - Outer mitochondrial membrane has acyl-CoA synthetase and glycerol phosphate acyltransferase.

Option C - Mitochondrial matrix has citric acid cycle enzymes, β-oxidation enzymes, and pyruvate dehydrogenase.

Option D - Intermembrane space has adenylyl kinase and creatine kinase. It is filled with H+ creating a proton gradient. 

 The reactions in oxidative phosphorylation and the arrangement of complexes that form the ETC are shown below.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman came with complaints of swelling in her hard palate. Biopsy from the swelling showed the following picture. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and biopsy showing hallmark cells point towards a diagnosis of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma. 

The biopsy shows characteristic large anaplastic cells, some containing horseshoe-shaped nuclei and voluminous cytoplasm called hallmark cells.

It is a type of  T-cell lymphoma that consists of large lymphoid cells.

This occurs due to rearrangements in the ALK gene and usually affects children and young adults. It frequently involves soft tissue and carries a good prognosis. T-cell lymphomas with similar morphology without ALK positivity occur in older adults and have a bad prognosis.

CD markers: T cell markers (CD3, CD4, CD8 etc) +, CD30+ and CD15-

questions.text: The optimum floor area  recommended per adult person in a living room is ________
questions.solution:
The optimum floor area recommended per adult person in a living room is 50 – 100 sq. ft.

Non-Rural Housing Standards in India:

Housing parameters

Description
Site

Elevated to protect from rains and floods.

Independent access to street.

Away from vector breeding sites and other pollutants like smoke, noise, dust.

Soil on which it is founded must be dry and safe.
Floor A pucca floor that is impermeable, easy to clean, free from cracks, damp-proof. Height of plinth must be 2 – 3 feet.
Walls 9 inch thick, strong, low heat capacity, weather resistant, unsuitable for harbourage of rats/vermin.
Roof Height not less than 10 feet (3m).
Rooms Number of rooms must be according to size of family but basic number is two.
Floor area A living room should have at least 120 sq. ft. of area for occupancy of more than 1 person and 100 sq. ft. for occupancy of only one person. 50 -100 sq. ft. floor area per person is optimum in a living room.
Cubic space 500 – 1000 cubic feet of air space per capita.
Windows At least 2 windows per room with one opening into an open space. Windows must be at a height of not more than 3 feet above ground. Window area must be 1/5th of floor area.
Lighting Daylight factor should be >1% over half the floor area.
Sanitary privy It is a must in every house.
Others Proper facilities for garbage disposal, bathing and washing and a good water supply.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who works in a glass manufacturing industry comes with complaints of abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and blueline on the gums. You suspect lead poisoning, which among the following is false about it?

choices.text: It is a notifiable and compensatable disease
Lead sulphide is the most toxic lead compound
Inhalation is the mode of absorption in most cases
d-penicillamine as chelating agent is effective

questions.solution:
All the options statements regarding lead poisoning are true except B, as lead sulphide is considered the least toxic among other lead compounds.

Lead poisoning/Plumbism is a notifiable and compensatable disease.

Lead is a metallic inorganic irritant poison.Poisoning is more common from chronic occupational exposure from industries that utilize lead.

Industries that utilize lead are glass manufacture, shipbuilding, printing and potteries, storage batteries, and rubber industries.

All lead compounds are toxic - lead arsenate, lead oxide, and lead carbonate are the most dangerous; lead sulphide is the least toxic.

Inhalation of fumes and dust of lead is the mode od absorption seen in most cases. Other modes are ingestion and absorption through the skin.

Plumbism/saturnism/chronic lead poisoning presents with

Mnemonic-ABCDEF

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsion, and coma)

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)

Management: d-penicillamine is reported to be an effective chelating agent.

questions.text: Blood spill in the operation theatre is cleaned with _____.
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills; it is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labeled containment.

questions.text: The type of strangulation shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The type of strangulation shown in the given image is garrotting.

Tightening of a noose around the neck by twisting a rod within the ligature is known as Garrotting. 

This was a form of judicial execution once employed in Spain. The rod-like object used to tighten the ligature is called a Spanish windlass - this may be a ruler, stick or a screwdriver.

Other options:

  • Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands. 
  • Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow.  Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind. Death occurs due to reflex cardiac arrest or asphyxia. 
  • Lynching - Putting a person to death by mob action for an alleged offence without a legal trial.

questions.text: Fleischer's ring is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Fleischer's ring is seen in keratoconus. Slit-lamp examination reveals Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone formed.

Keratoconus or the conical cornea is a bilateral non-inflammatory progressive condition of the axial part of the cornea. Central or paracentral thinning of the cornea and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea are pathognomonic. This is attributed to mucopolysaccharide and collagen tissue synthesis defects. 

Clinical features of the condition include defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism. Light sensitivity and ocular irritation may also be present. Complications include acute hydrops following the rupture of Descemet's membrane.

Deep, vertical stromal striae (Vogt lines) that disappear with external pressure are characteristic. Retinoscopy shows a scissoring reflex. The bulging of the lower lid in the downgaze, called Munson's sign, is shown in the image below.

The severity of the condition is graded based on keratometry. Corneal topography is a diagnostic modality with the highest sensitivity for early cases.

Intacs or intracorneal ring segments are useful in moderate cases due to their flattening effect. Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses, corneal collagen cross-linking with riboflavin, and keratoplasty are the other treatment modalities.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: The concept of the procedure was introduced by Goldmann.
It is used to treat after cataract
It is based on the Imbert-Fick law
It is used to investigate glaucoma

questions.solution:
The instrument shown is an applanation tonometer, which is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). 

Tonometers are used to measure intraocular pressure. There are two types of tonometers. They are indentation and applanation tonometers. Increased intraocular pressure is seen in cases of glaucoma.

Applanation tonometry is more accurate. The concept behind the procedure was introduced by Goldmann. The applanation tonometer measures the amount of force needed to applanate (flatten) a known corneal area based on the Imbert-Fick law. Imbert-Fick law states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A).

P = W/A

Goldmann tonometer, tono-pen, Perkin's applanation tonometry, and pneumatic tonometer are all based on the principle of applanation tonometry. 

Indentation tonometry is based on the principle that a plunger will indent more on a soft eye than a hard eye. Schiotz tonometer is the most widely used tonometer as it is cheap and hand-held. However, it can give false readings if used in an eye with abnormal scleral rigidity.

*Note - After cataract, otherwise known as posterior capsular opacification, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. Treatment includes posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser.

questions.text: In a community of 5000, the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people. The number of pregnant females is ?
questions.solution:
The number of pregnant females is 165.

Step 1: In the given question, the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people i.e 30 children are born from pregnant mothers for every 1000 people. Therefore there are 30 pregnant females per 1000 population.

Step 2: Since the total population is 5000, the total no of pregnant females = 30 x 5000/1000 = 150 

Step 3: We should also consider the pregnancy wastage i.e 10% of total live births =10 x 150/100=15 (since some pregnancies may not result in live birth i.e abortions and stillbirths, a correction factor of 10% is to be added to avoid the underestimation of the number of pregnancies)

Step 4: Total pregnant females = total live birth + pregnancy wastage = 150+15=165.

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you noticed the following wound shown in the image below. You would document this wound as:
questions.solution:
The given image is most likely suggestive of a stab wound because of the presence of fish-tails.

A stab wound is a type of mechanical injury that is produced when force is applied along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object like a knife, sword, chisel, needle, screwdriver, etc into the depth of the body. The characteristics are

  • The margins of the wound are clean-cut and inverted. 
  • The length of the wound is slightly less than the width of the weapon. 
  • The width of the wound corresponds to the maximum possible width of the blade. 
  • The depth of the wound is greater than the length and width of the external injury on the skin surface.
  • The shape of the surface wound depends on the type of weapon, cutting surface, the direction of thrust, cleavage lines, etc.
  • The shape of the wound is usually triangular or wedge-shaped. Depending on the type of instrument used, one side of the wound may be sharp, while another side may be blunt.
  • The blunt side may show small splits at each corner called fishtailing as shown below. 

 

Option A- An incised wound is a clean-cut wound made with a sharp-edged instrument, through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels. The length of the wound is more than the depth and width.

The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is usually spindle-shaped. The depth is more at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

 

Option B- Chop wounds or slash wounds are the wounds produced by chopping motion, made with heavy and sharp weapons like axe, cleave, etc. The dimensions of the wound correspond to the crosssection of the penetrating part of the weapon. The margins are sharp and show slight abrasion and bruising with the destruction of underlying organs. The presence of an incised wound on the skin with an underlying fracture or deep grove in the bone indicates a chop wound. The image below shows a chop wound.

 
Option C- Lacerated wounds are characterised by the presence of swallow tails. The margins are ragged, irregular, and uneven. Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails. Swallow tail in a lacerated wound is shown below.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to you with complaints of weight loss, hoarseness of voice, and difficulty in breathing. On direct laryngoscopy, a mass involving both the vocal cords with extension to the subglottis is seen. Cords are immobile and there is no lymph node involvement. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of glottic carcinoma. What is the next step in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of glottic carcinoma involving immobile vocal cords with extension to the subglottis suggests that the tumour belongs to the T3 stage. The treatment of choice is concurrent chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

TNM classification of glottic carcinoma (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002)

Stage Description
T1 Tumour limited to vocal cord(s) with normal mobility
T1a Tumour limited to one vocal cord
T1b Tumour involves both vocal cords
T2a Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with normal vocal cord mobility
T2b Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with impaired vocal cord mobility
T3 Tumour limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or  minor thyroid cartilage erosion
T4a Tumour invades thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissue beyond the larynx
T4b Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures

Treatment of laryngeal cancers:

T stage Treatment
T1a TLM > RT
T1b (mid-cord lesion) RT/TLM > OPL
T2a RT/TLM > OPL
T2b RT ± CT > TLM
T3 CRT
T4a TL> CRT
T4b Palliative management

TLM: Transoral laser microsurgery; RT: Radiotherapy; OPL: Open partial laryngectomy; CT: Chemotherapy; CRT: Chemoradiotherapy, TL: Total laryngectomy.
